As a big fan of Dark Souls I and Dark Souls II, I am greatly pleased with Dark Souls III. The gameplay is closer to DS2 than DS1. The game mechanics are great. I love the idea of using focus to cast spells instead of having a certain amount of casts like in the previous games. Magic is a valuable playstyle.   I found the bosses' design more creative than those from DS2, although there weren't as much bosses. There weren't any cheap copies like there were in the previous two games (like asylum demon/demon firesage, Dragonslayèer knights, Ornstein/old dragonslayer) and the boss fights was interesting and diverse. There were very difficult bosses and easy bosses as well.  Enemies keep respawning (like DS1, unlike DS2). The poison mechanic is also changed in that it works wat slower than the previous games, making it less dangerous. Items are easier to use and the interface in general is great.   There are a lot of callbacks to Dark Souls 1, which you might or might not find a good thing. There aren't as many DS2 callbacks, if I remember. Story wise, it's the same as DS1 & DS2 in that there's no clear story, but the story is hidden instead.   The combat system is great, but there're some instances that were very annoying and just seemed unfair. There have been countless times when my attacks were deflected by the wall or a pillar, but there weapons sometimes hit you straight through a solid wall.  There are some other negative points about this game, though. First of all, the game's map isn't as intertwined as DS1's. Also, at the beginning, the game might feel a bit linear, although that changes after the first couple of area's. In the different area's, there are a lot of shortcuts that can be opened (by opening a door or kicking a ladder). When it comes to the world, one other problem I have is the amount of swamp-like/watery area's, which are very annoying cause they slow you down and might poison you. There are at least 5 area's that I can think of (I won't spoil which ones).   Another problem there is are online covenant-related issues. There are some covenants that appear not to work (Blue Sentinels, Darkmoon, ... ). These covenants are supposed to send you to other players when they're attacked by invading players, yet you never get summoned. Cause some of these covenants don't work as they should, farming the items required to deepen your relation with the covenant becomes a big hassle because their drop rates are extremely small (I'm looking at the Proof of a concord Kept item).  The camera sometimes screws you over when tracking an enemy (I'm looking at the Nameless King). I have played this game with my controller, so I can't say anything about the pc (mouse/keyboard) controls.   There're a lot of other positive and negative elements in this game that I haven't mentioned yet because I currently can't think of them. Also, I might have mentioned more negative points (and went in more depth with them) than positive points, but don't let that mislead you about the quality and greatness of the game.   Overall, I loved this game and if you enjoyed the previous Dark Souls games, I advise you to purchase this game as well.

You start as a worthless dead being that is not even worth setting on fire to preserve the dying world. You set out to go through lost kingdoms, forbidden places and fight unspeakable beings. It is a journey of a game, and it has plenty of places to explore, a large variety of enemies, characters with distinct personalities and motives, and abilities you can use to your liking creating a playstyle that truly fits you.  If you are looking for multiplayer experience then you will have the opportunity to help other players, or invade them or simultaneously both at the same time. There are various in-game groups that will give you motivation via a simple reward system (per assist or per kill, depending on the group) that will give you a currency item, and you will be able to exchange it for something as you level up with that group by offering the currency to it.  I feel that it has the best online community right now, as people are not aggressive in-game, rarely you get to hear someone being angry, frustrated, and generally being an idiot with an attitude. Some players with a microphone (it is optional to enable as a feature) and the subreddit, and wiki on fextralife are full of information, and discussion about the game, from the mechanics to the lore and features.   On the subreddit specifically there's also presence of Namco's community manager, so you can get to know things almost directly from the developers through the community manager. This is a huge plus for me, since I've been a fan of Bungie for a while, since their Halo days where they kept a close tie with their community.  This game will offer you an experience; it will be a challenge in many places, and in others it will be easy fully depending on your playstyle, and ability to adapt quickly to the variety of location and enemies.

There are many Amazing ones, however there are a few disappointing and/or lazy ones.   -Connection between area's and maith path is linear in nature, however there are many shortcuts and ways to reach certain destinations within the area's. There are multiple hidden area's, including one that leads to one of the best boss fights in the game.  -The main hub is disconnected from the world, however fromsoft uses this to their advantage by giving you good reasons to return to the hub to see what has occured.   -Npc questlines are long with multiple choices that change the quest.  -Poise is curently disabled by the devs, meaning pvp is flooded by fast attacking r1 spammers.   -Matchmaking with certain auto-summon covenants is broken as well.   Take from this what you will, but this game is veruy fun. I've put 122 hours into it so far.

Disclaimer: This is a my opinion and my native language isn't English. Beware of grammatical errors and also typos.  This review is for PvE since I van not played PvP and thus have no opinion on that subject.   TL:DR, skip to the end! List of Pros and Cons will be at the end too!    This game is a very good succesor of the other souls games, thus including Bloodborne and Demon Souls, in my opinion since they did not lose track of what was good and bad in the previous games. They combined the older Souls games' indepth (but easy to understand) leveling system and combined it with the faster paced gameplay of Bloodborne which made the game a lot easier imo, but also made it a lot more streamlined. The faster pacing you can get with this game also makes it more strategic imo since you have more ways too fight your enemy now. Weapon Skills also help, but at least I myself dont use the weapon skills on most weapons since they either take up precious FP or the skill isn't any good to me, but even though I don't really use them I still really like the fact that they're there.  But this game isn't just a good succesor, it's also a great game for new players since you still have to start somewhere and why not at this one. The backstory from the other games isn't needed for the most part since this one has it's own story plus references. The only reason I wouldn't want to start at this one is because you will probably have a hard time adapting to the slower paced older games, but this depends on the player ofcourse.  Gameplay wise I really don't have any complaints about the game, not even in comparison to the older games or other games like this, thus let's look at all the stuff aroiund gameplay like story, character building, little stuff, etc.  I myself am not much of a person for story and like to actually play more than listen to some old guy explaining stuff about the world and that's why I really like the Souls' aproach where most of the (back)story comes from items and other little things that you pick up whilst playing the game. For instance: Spoiler alert! The final boss actually uses a very familliar moveset at one of the fases of the bossfight. This ties this game to another game in the series.  Since I'm not really all that much of a story guy I really like it when you can create your own character and I love the little things they used in Bloodborne like saving templates and stuff that have moved over to this game and I'm also really happy they actually used the same classes as in Demon Souls which gave a little more variation and replayability.  Last but not least the fact that you can actually play in Offline mode is a blessing for PvE'ers like myself since I don't have to cheat the system to get this done anymore.   And for the one thing I didn't like about the game was that it was pretty short imo, only 60 + Hours with farming for Sunlight Medals, but this can also be contributed to the fact that I really think this is the second easiest Souls game, Bloodborne being the only one I think is easier. To be honest the short lifespan of this game isn't really all that bad since you needto go through the game at least three times to get all the items unles you ask someone to give you some of the exlusive NG+, NG++ and NG+++ stuff.    List of Pros and Cons (and I've added Neutrals which are more like noteworthy stuff that isn't really a Pro or a Con):  PROS:  - Awesome new weapons skills. - Huge aray of weapons with their own movesets. - Cool character customization plus builds (Skills). - A lot of (back)story with references to the other Dark Souls games' lore. - Offline mode for the PvE'ers among us. - Able to fight most enemies (if not all) in your own style. - Fashion Souls/Roleplaying. - Replayability. - There are more, but I can't think of any at the moment.  NEUTRALS:  - Way easier than the other Dark Souls games and Demon Souls, but this may be attributed to the fact that I had already played the other Souls games.  - Some builds are pretty lackluster to begin with, but get pretty awesome neer the second halve or even endgame. - I wish they had implemented some kind of trick weapon in the game since that was what most intrigued me in Bloodborne. - There may be more, but I can't think of any at the moment.  CON: - Too short (Hopefully the DLCs make up for this) 60 Hours with a lot of grinding/farming for items like Sunlightmedals.  - There may be more, but I can't think of any at the moment.   Overall a great game with awesome new features, but a little bit on the short side, for Souls veterans, but also a game that you can step into if you like these kinds of games. I believe the game is still worth the full price because of the replayability, but like I said this is all my opinion and I'm indeed a big fan of Fromsoftware's work.  If you've read everything, I would like to say I'm sorry for having you put up with all my typos and grammatical errors. Hopefully this review was helpful.

Fantastic addition and (supposed) conclusion of the Dark Souls series. The Greatest Hits collection of all 'Souls' games, which has it's cons, but makes a incredibly fun to play game. If there're things to have some nitpicks about, it's the combat build balancing and the fact, that the story feels too reliant on the first game. First thing is about the fact, that Souls went from ability to play shielded knight in Demon's without much issue to Souls 3, where your guard will be broken way too often to not be more reliant on dodges. While it's not an issue for my styles of play, it can annoy those, who liked to be more on the defensive as even simplest enemies will easily stagger them. Second thing is about the fact, that DkS III feels like a very unexpected direct sequel to the first game after a much more vague 'set in the same world and maybe even same place but many centuries later' second game. It feels like Silent Hill 3 after 2 decided to do 'it's own thing', except Dark Souls 3 doesn't tell us everything and ruin the mystique of the world. There's still magic in it's vagueness, but it often feels like the developers felt the need to close the story they told in the first game in the most definite way possible by making you re-live some of the old moments and even revisit some old places almost as you remember them. The game, in general, feels very much like a 'Greatest Hits re-recorded by a band many years later, with more experience and still a lot of passion' thing. And as with music records of this kind, sometimes the more experienced new arrangements of old songs lose some of their raw flawed beauty. Game never feels like it was done 'by the book'. It still surprises in many unexpected ways with bosses, twists to usual mechanics and such, moreso than other Souls games. It feels, again, more of a rich adventure with RPG, platforming, action, clever tricks and amazing levels, rather than a very good action RPG, Dark Souls 2 was. Which also means, that some of the nuances from 2 are also gone here. And some people won't like it. Some people won't also like that it's 'easier' than previous Souls games. Things are still deadly and dangerous and full of STUFF that helps or kills you, but you will rarely get truly stuck on some part. There are few unfun sections and not particularly good bosses, but the game this time around feels more generous towards the player. Punishing the mistakes, but in a less harsh way than especially Dark Souls 1 did. There are rarely ever occasions to farm for souls or upgrade materials, if you're thorough in exploration, it rarely feels like you're hitting a wall when you go forward - it feels like an hill you need to climb, but it's fun and rewarding, more than ever before. It feels like this is the balance they always strived for but couldn't really do right before Bloodborne and Dark Souls 3. And PC version is very good, but with some issues. At the time of writing some people are having severe issues, though no one I know. But it's something to be aware of - PC configurations are very different, after all, and for some people there might be huge issues. For me, the main issue was strangely inconsistant, but high, framerate which sometimes screwed up dodge/attack timings by a lot. Hopefully, this will be adressed in patches. For now, I'm sadly putting this away and await for hopefully great DLCs. Don't dissapoint, From, the hopes are very high.:)

So here's my thoughts after 2 play throughs, plenty of grinding to find obscure items, and countless hours in pvp  In some ways, Dark souls 3 did disappoint me. It doesn't have the wonderfully crafted and beautifiully interconnected world of the original. It also abandoned many of the progressive elements of the sequal, such as the huge scope in how you built your character and the viability of many difffent builds, and the epic power fest that was dual wielding. It also doesn't bring much new to the table aside from the weapon arts. There is also a fair amount of recycled assests from 1 and 2...  However, that said, Dark Souls 3 is still my fav game of 2016 and I've sunk ridiculous amount of hours into it. The combat in the game is faster, more fluid, and wholey addicting. The world, monsters and armour designs are stunning, intricate and detailed. Co op remains jolly good fun, and for the first time in the series I've done a lot off pvp, which can be annoying when people cheese the fun out of it, but overall i had a blast. The bosses were a bit hit an miss, but some of the best in the series are here, like the Abyss Watchers, Nameless King, Yhorm and the Dancer. I also enjoyed the lore and characters of this one, especially our old friend the onion knight.  while there is a lot of salt on the message boards about DS3 (waah poise! waah invasions! waaah ganking phantoms) surrounding PVP, I've really enjoyed it, although without a dueling covenant it can become a bit stale after a while. Dueling and fight clubs are really fun, and although invading is not really my thing, I do like finding creative ways to troll people (like posing as an NPC and then doing something hilarious) coz I'm not nasty enough to kill someone most of the time. Invading can be fun when you have 3 on 3 battles though. Although lag and glitches will give you a headache, and there's still too much potential for ultra cheese builds to take the fun out of things ( fighting a one shot build using tears of denial = you lose every time or how that silly hornet ring that gives pretty much insta-kill on a parry), i went in with the mind set to just have a laugh, and laugh i did.   I've loved (almost) every hour with the game, despite its flaws and can't wait for the DLC. It really is a love letter to fans, and the new faster combat really did it for me.  Update 1 - First DLC Ashes of Ariandal is an ok diversion. It's gorgeous, and has some interesting lore implications which harken back to the original, but overal it is lacking in content. It'll only take 2or 3 hours, only has 2 (although spectacular) boss fights. The PVP stuff is pretty cool though, and it does have some interesting new items. hopefully the next DLC is much better.

Dark Souls III feels like a mirage in a desert after the monotone emptiness of single player games that might be open, beautiful, and immersive with both a great story and great gameplay. Unfortunately, their story always ends. Just like the anti-climax after completing a great book. It’s a certain sadness over such a loss, but also an emptiness because of what used to give you entertainment no longer does. It was just a story you got told or told yourself, and when it is done, it’s DONE.   This is where Dark Souls III differs. It is not just one story, it’s many, and how many and how they end is up to you. It incorporates an ambiguous story with a dark and adrenaline pumping, nerve wrecking, angst for what you are going to face around the next corner. All the while the feeling that you must avoid dying because of what you might lose. Now here comes what makes Dark Souls III REALLY unique. You can do all this while sharing it with friends and foes that join you or you join, or that invade you, or maybe you are the one invading, hunting down others for their precious embers?  Whatever path you choose, you will end up with many stories and a strong sense of accomplishment. Some stories will be made while alone, others can be shared with strangers and maybe with friends communicated only via a few gestures that cover the most basic emotions. You will affect other people and other people will affect as you travel across this strange and brutal land. You will die, and if you stick around you will learn to deal with it, most likely grow on a more personal level.  For myself, I needed this game. It got everything I didn’t even know I wanted. It is a perfect 10. And if I were to recommend only one game, this would be it.

Dark Souls III is a culmination of some of the best aspects of the previous Souls games, creating a more fitting sequel to the Dark Souls series then Dark Souls II was. Dark Souls III does try to stand out however, bringing faster combat, faster enemies and bosses to the table, while still maintaining a strong emphasis on patience and situational awareness the original Dark Souls had, albeit with a more linear world.  You once again begin the game with a short cutscene, with a little more to go on then in previous installments. The Lords of Cinder have left their thrones, and presumably you’re the one destined to fetch them like a kindergarden teacher gathering children for naptime. You quickly find your way to the Firelink Shrine to meet the new/old cast of characters, who greet you with the usual creepy cackling. Firelink Shrine feels a little more welcoming and safe than previous games, sharing similarities with the Nexus from Demon Souls as it’s almost entirely disconnected from the rest of the gameworld. Although it still carries the themes of Dark Souls unlike Majula from Dark Souls II, this new Firelink Shrine doesn’t really compare to the previous one in my opinion, I much prefered when the hub-area was actually in the centre of the world I was exploring, much like Dark Souls did.  You’ll find in Dark Souls III that it’s exceedingly difficult to go the wrong way, since Firelink Shrine now serves as a disconnected hub-world where you teleport to the areas you’ll be exploring. The world is still intertwined and connected once you’re removed from Firelink Shrine, however these intertwined pathways and shortcuts are only present within their own individual areas, while the original Dark Souls had pathways and shortcuts  between  their areas. A fine example would be that Blighttown was connected to the Depths, and Drakes Valley, giving you an option of which way you would like to approach Blighttown from. Dark Souls III has linear paths between areas, not offering any options on how to approach them.  Combat is improved in Dark Souls III, boasting far faster combat than previous installments and  weapon arts , which are a new set of attacks which are specific to the weapon/magic you’re using. However, they’re limited by the new FP bar(Focus Points), this helps to significantly mix up combat style, offering more variety in attacks. As previously mentioned, this faster combat is done in such a way that patience and learning enemy attack patterns is still highly encouraged, and due to the quicker speed of combat, there is less downtime when waiting for an enemy to be vulnerable. It feels different, and will take some adjusting - but it’s a welcome addition in my eyes.  The world this time around feels more like Dark Souls, unlike Dark Souls II. Providing that same depressing and grim beauty we have come to enjoy and love. Dark Souls III goes further with the entire apocalyptic theme, the land of Lothric truly feels like it's dying, like the world is coming to an end. The NPCs also feel much more familiar, some previous NPCs actually returning for this third game. The characters and dialog are much better this time around too, however it still leaves something to be desired, as many of the NPCs have almost nothing to say until the closing hours of the game, honestly giving me some frustration as I was playing. It’s a great improvement from Dark Souls II, but still isn’t much better than the original Dark Souls. Characters are mostly memorable, but much of the dialog is relatively weak.  The typical storytelling and lore returns to Dark Souls III, making the player put it together like a puzzle instead of clearly stating it. It’s also in a similar fashion to the original Dark Souls, not making the same mistakes Dark Souls II made. I was worried when starting Dark Souls III that any mention of previous Souls games in the lore would be fanservice, however it didn’t take long to realize that there was actually a lot of care put into what was mentioned. The only fanservice that I felt was being able to obtain the Sun Set, however this was obtained via a non-obtuse way and wasn’t just found lying about in a chest. Overall Dark Souls III’s lore and story is handled really well, and feels like a good conclusion to the series, regardless of the questions which may remain unanswered.  Dark Souls III isn’t perfect, the linearity compared to the original Dark Souls left me wanting, and many of the mechanics which were previously favored have been heavily altered and changed. Poise being the finest example as it’s essentially non-existent, which seemed to throw a wrench at the PvP community. Many of the covenant systems also seems to be broken or not very useful, which heavily affects the online play. It’s unfortunate that the last supposed Dark Souls game seemed to have really messed up the online play for PvPers, however the PvEers seem largely unaffected by these changes. Aside from these glaring issues, Dark Souls III serves as a wonderful sequel to Dark Souls, offering new aspects to the combat and spicing it up with its speed and variety in attacks. If you have yet to play a Souls game, I suggest playing Dark Souls before Dark Souls III, and treating Dark Souls II as a disconnected additional game, as you don’t need to play it to understand the other two games.  If you enjoyed previous Souls games for its lore and PvE, Dark Souls III provides much of the same with a few welcomed additions, however PvP has been significantly hampered due to the changes with Poise.

This game is probably one of the most solid entries in the Souls series. It doesn't make any major missteps, the level design is consistently good and aside from one lategame boss the bosses themselves are all serviceable.  It's a game that doesn't do a whole lot wrong, but it doesn't do anything spectacularly either. Whereas Dark Souls 1 could be very up and down, it had lots of really memorable and amazing moments. DaS3 is kinda like DaS2 in that a lot of it's most important moments end up being kind of forgetable and this is especially the case with boss theme music. In fact the music has the exact same problem as 2 did; it all just blends together into a mush and you can't remember anything. But you can say the same for the bossfights in general; outside of one or two near the end of the game they're all just kind of... there. They're not bad or anything but they don't stand out either. This is kind of exemplified with the final boss fight; it's mechanically a really, really good fight (it's not ♥♥♥♥ing nashandra or allant basically). But there's none of the emotional build-up and impact of DaS1 or Bloodborne, despite the game trying it's best to copy aspects of the final fight in 1.  And that's really the only major flaw with this game. It's the 5th in a series, of which we've been getting 1 of each year for the past 3. I think there's immense replayability in the Souls formula, but at this point the Dark Souls setting is starting to get old. The reuse of so many different weapons, items, NPC's and enemies ends up hurting the game more than helping it. Not just in a sense of it being shallow pandering fanservice, but it actively hurts one of the main draws of the series: exploring and finding new things and new lore. I struggled throughout my playthrough to stay engaged for long periods of time because I was finding the same ♥♥♥♥ I'd always found, talking to same or very similar NPC's with no new twists and finding the exact same lore for the most part.  DaS3 really suffers if you've played BB or are already really invested and familiar the series. The callbacks could either be really fun to you, or they could make your eyes roll and wish for something new. Thing is we already got something new. BB used aspects and cliches of the series, but so much of it felt fresh and it was in a genuinely new and interesting setting and it was released a year previously. It already kind of felt like From and the Souls series had moved on, or were at least attempting to try interesting spins on the formula. But DaS3 ends up feeling like a step backwards.  That might not be a bad thing for you though and DaS3 is certainly not a bad game. I'm just very tired of the Dark Souls setting and didn't think any numbered sequels were ever neccessary. If you have less experience with the series, don't care as much and haven't played Bloodborne then this could easily be your fav of the series and you'll probably love a lot of things in it.

GAMEPLAY Dark Souls III excels in pretty much every aspect but suffers due to technical issues. As expected the base gameplay mechanics are probably the strongest reason to play this game. There are the basic light and heavy attacks, blocking, parrying, and two handing weapons that many players will be accustomed to. There are also some new things to try out as well. By infusing some elements and mechanics from Bloodborne, the combat is strengthened even more. Something new to Dark Souls III is weapon arts, which spice up the combat even more. Though they don’t necessarily need to be used for regular combat encounters, when used properly they can make some bosses easier to defeat. There is one boss with which it is almost mandatory to use a particular weapon art to defeat. Some may find this gimmicky, but it was quite enjoyable. Pvp is also a good place to experiment with weapon arts.  The design and placement of enemies and bosses may seem familiar, but this is in no way a detriment to the game. Players are still given the heart pounding experience as they get their opponent’s health bar lower and lower. Battles taken for granted can easily go bad, but when cautious and calm you will usually be able to make it out of whatever situation you are facing. Knowing when to use estus flasks to heal, or take advantage of a critical hit that just staggered an opponent are equally important. When everything is clicking and an adversary is bested, there is the thrilling sense of accomplishment that every player remembers and looks forward to when they are defeated numerous times prior. The combat feels significantly faster, almost as much as Bloodeborne, which should not bother too many people. The other gameplay element that makes boss fights even better is the phased/secondary forms that they take after a certain percentage of their health has been depleted. Even if the change is as slight as movement speed or attack frequency, the player must be able to keep their cool and adapt to win.  Collecting items is a pretty big part of the game, and makes exploration of the dark and mostly unfriendly environments well worth it. Whether it be picking up an outfit off a long dead corpse, or attacking titanite lizards, it feels great picking up new gear. Many times the outfits and armor will have beneficial properties for the next or current area. It pays to be mindful of stats such as poison or bleed resistance when discovering what hazards and elemental damage enemies’ deal in a new area. Weapon drops can seem a little unsatisfactory or redundant further into the game, especially if the player has been significanlty upgrading a few weapons that fit their play style. Being able to sell items at will back at the main bonfire is a good remedy when finding weapons that seem unnecessary or unhelpful. One of if not the best improvement made for Dark Souls III is in regards to the cooperative play. Souls III has the best and most easily accessible co-op out of From Software’s entire role playing catalogue to date. There is a new option in the system menu to make coop, particularly with friends easier. This is the password option. When using this tool, players with the same password chosen will only be able to see summon signs of others that have also chosen that password. There is no level cap when using passwords, and the summon signs will appear almost instantaneously. For these reasons, it makes trying to cooperatively play through the entire game a very enticing option though it will require everybody to play each area/boss two or three times. Aside from this major enhancement the other general rules apply. The host must be embered (embers are Dark Souls IIIs version humanity/human effigy), and they must not have already defeated the area boss. The gameplay is the biggest reason to buy Dark Souls III, but it is not the only one.  LEVEL DESIGN/ATMOSPHERE The level design is impeccable and much improved from Dark Souls II. Although the entire world is not as intricately connected as Dark Souls, the player will find that there will be a good amount of well-placed loop backs and shortcuts to pre-existing bonfires throughout most of the areas. There are a few exceptions however, particularly in the later mandatory and optional environments. There are some lazily designed shortcuts that are not cleverly placed, and/or that don’t make as much logical sense. There are also a few bonfires that are placed way too close to each other; one comes to mind that is literally ten to twenty steps away from the previous one. As mentioned previously, this is only true for a small minority of the zones. Otherwise the level design is very well done. The world and lore are also very good even though the story remains a bit more abstract than most may be used to. Each area has some story to tell, that one can probably figure out by looking at the condition of structures, and the enemies within them. To add even more to the world are the NPCs that can be found throughout, with sub questlines that are easy to miss if not listening closely enough to what they say. Fans will also be delighted to see the return of some very awesome NPCs from the original Dark Souls. The atmosphere in about ninety percent of the areas is dark and depressing, which is not surprising, seeing as the word ‘DARK’ is the first word in the title. There are a couple more bright areas, one of which is optional and requires a few steps to get to. These are a nice surprise, considering the contrast that they provide to the overall theme of the game.  The other element that completes the atmosphere of Dark Souls III is the soundtrack. As with the other FromSoftware RPGs, the soundtrack is made up of grand orchestral instruments and prominent operatic choirs, particularly during boss fights. Although it may not be as good as some previous soundtracks, it does what it is supposed to and adds the final layer to the world that manages to capture a player.  TECHNICAL When it comes to the technical performance Dark Souls III has some shortcomings. Those who love unlocked framerates will be disappointed, as it is locked at sixty frames per second. There is also a weird issue with 7XX series NVidia brand GPUs and some AMD GPUs as well. If the lighting quality is set to anything but “low”, the game will crash. This happens when cloth physics on an object such as a cape and an object with heavy lighting effects such as a bonfire appear on screen at the same time. When the game first released, one would have to remember to switch the lighting quality back to 'low' every time they booted up the game. This led to some frustrating crashes. The issue with the lighting being reset has since been solved by a patch. Another minor annoyance is the fact that controller button prompts still show up when using a keyboard and mouse, making it harder for those who wish to use this input method. With that out of the way, the overall graphical fidelity is significantly improved from the previous titles. With this unfortunately comes some frame drops during some boss encounters, and when the save game indicator appears at the top right of the screen. Most users with a mid to high end graphics card will be able to get the game to run at sixty frames most of the time.  As it is Dark Souls III is a great game, which could have been amazing if not for the technical issues that it had. Still it is well worth the money and should be purchased for its consistent world, atmosphere, and stellar gameplay.  Gameplay 9/10 Level Design/Atmosphere 10/10 Technical 6/10  Total 8.3/10

So after spending some time in Lothric I thought it would be a good idea to share some of my thoughts and concerns regarding the supposedly final installment of Dark Souls. I will stay out of most story related things in this review, to keep it as spoiler free as possible.   -  Starting with the PvE. It's absolutely phenomenal. The combat is probably the most fluid and fun I've had with a souls game. Stamina regens much faster, rolls are faster, everything is faster paced. There is a new mechanic called 'Weapon Arts' which really brings out the 'personality' of each kind of weapon. To use Weapon Arts, you must spend Focus Points(FP). If you played Demon's Souls, think of the magic bar in that game. It's essentially the same thing. If you did not play demon's souls, it's like a limited resource bar that is consumed to cast spells, miracles etc and Weapon Arts. It can be replenished by drinking from you Ashen Estus Flask, which has a limited number of uses, but you can choose to sacrifice charges from your normal Estus to give your Ashen Estus more chugs.  -  They yet again did a great job with enemy and boss designs, altough I feel the AI is a lot more aggressive, like bloodborne. But jesus christ, the dogs in this game is probably the most annoying ones yet. Kill the dogs first. Always.  -  Level design feels great, but not as great as Dark souls 1 did. Sad how they seemingly can't quite nail down that original masterpiece when it comes to shortcuts and such. Feels a lot like bloodborne.  There's a loot of connection to the original Dark Souls, if you're a fan of DS1, you're in for a real good treat.  -  Side quests here are probably the most tedious ones yet. There are so many 'if you miss this now, TOO BAD. CYA IN NG+' moments it's insane. I even missed out on an entire covenant because I missed something earlier in the game, and it was too late to fix it. So, yet again, you're off to reading guides if you want to stand ANY chance to complete a side quest and not screw up. While on the topic of Covenants, I might aswell mention that you no longer have to run back and fourth to join other covenants. Instead, when you get asked to join a covenant, you recieve a badge, which you can then equip to instantly join that covenant, and you can change covenant on the go, as many times as you want.   -  They added bloodborne's password co-op system, including the level scaling, so you can now co-op with your friends, regardless of levels. Good job FROM. This system is amazing.  -  The game looks amazing, and runs OK. Unfortunaly I have to keep my game on Low, but it's not much of an issue as it's absolutely beautiful, even on low. For reference, I have a R9 280 and a FX-6100 OC to 4.0ghz, and I get 60 fps in some areas, and never dip below 30. There's been several performance patches rolled out since release, so it's slowly but steady gotten better.  Moving on to PvP. I'm not too sure what to make of this yet, but it's not exactly loved, unfortunaly, because PvP is one of the big reasons a lot of people keep coming back to a souls game after they've finished everything in PvE. As an avid PvPer myself, I'm quite disappointed. The added mechanics such as faster movement, rolls and less stamina consumption that made PvE feel much better, unfortunaly made PvP take a step into the wrong direction. Not only that, but theres a few other things that made DS3's pvp feel worse aswell:    Can't be invaded unless boss is alive. Huge step down from DS2, that system worked so well.   Can't be invaded unless you consume an ember(Humanity/Human effigy) Again, they made it work so well in DS2, I really wish it had stayed.   Nearly ALL my invasions has been versus host+1 or 2 phantoms. It seems like the game sort of priorities invading hosts with phantoms.    Blue eye orbs are gone, and with that so is the Sin mechanic. So the only way to get summoned as a blue is to pray and hope that people have Way of the blue covenant equipped. Not that much of a problem early game, but becomes a real issue later into the game.   Invaders can chug estus this time around, and it's not that much of a problem, the problem is that chugging is sooooooo much faster in ds3 compared to other souls games.   Backstepping just is not good anymore. It had it's use in DS2, but not anymore.   Guard break removed. Kick is back though.   Arenas removed. This one really hit me hard. I had a great time in in BoB arena.   Poise is nonexistant. I read somewhere that there is a poise system actually build in to the game, similar to DS1's poise system, but for some reason it's turned off. so you get stagged by pretty much everything, unless you attack with a weapon that has Hyperarmor.   With all this in mind, I can see a lot of people, myself included, going back to DS2 for their PvP fix, which I think is quite sad. I'm not giving up on DS3 PvP yet though.  - - - - -  So, do I recommend this game? Absolutely. Veteran or Newcomer, you're in for a wild ride for what might be, the final installment of Dark Souls. May the flames guide thee.

Great game, has entertaining PvE and PvP. Combat is the main selling point. High difficult with an extremely high expectancy to die often since the game is about learning the areas and adjusting. Enemies respawn when you die/rest to restore your potions (you get restorable HP/mana potions basically). You also lose all your souls (in-game currency) when you die although if you manage to make it back to where you die you can reclaim them all. If you die again before reclaiming your souls they're lost forever. Decent variety in what you can do PvP wise. You can invade other player's games using the red orb in which case you can get ember (increased hp and ability to summon other people into your game) as well as an item to unlock rewards from a covenant (NPC-based guild basically). You can also be summoned to protect people in their world against those invaders to earn a different reward for a different covenant. The remaining options in this type of PvP is to be the host (person who's being invaded) and fight or summon other players to protect you. The other type of PvP is a duel/fight club mode. You can summon/be summoned to duel somebody in your world or their world depending on who summoned who through an item you get that lets you place a summmoning sign on the ground. There are also 'fight clubs' that players make by summoning a bunch of people and letting them duel each other. This is most apparent in a later part in the game on a castle area that's fitting for dueling.  Pros:  PvP is very enjoyable and skill-based, although some balance issues with certain weapons, but overall a balanced game where you can upgrade most weapon and be viable in PvP. Spacing, maximizing i-frames during rolling, playing to your weapon's strength (animation speed, super armor, range, stunlock etc), and stamina management are the key parts of PvP.  PvP has limits on who you can invade/help that takes into account how good your gear is and the game automatically scales down people who exceed the range. This only happens when you and a friend set a password to bypass the restriction as far as I know.  PvE is surprisingly enjoyable as well coming from a person who loathes PvE in the majority of games. The knight type mobs are my personal favorite since they function somewhat like a player. There are also NPCs that can invade your game like normal players that function a lot like an actual player.  Cons:  Some weapons have questionable balance like the Estoc at least in lower tier PvP in the game. You basically spam thrust with it and can melt people.  The way the game calculates damage makes mixed damage weapons pretty bad. Quality builds (STR/DEX) or builds that combine STR or DEX with another stat like INT or Faith are mainly king in PvP. This reduces the variety in build opportunities that hopefully will be patched to let elemental infusions be worth it.  For PvPers, there is mild phantom range when fighting, but that is to be expected in this type of game since it'd be pretty miserable if you had to perfect connect with the enemy's model to do damage. Fights would drag on forever.  PvP invasions can be frustrating for both sides when one side refuses to fight. If you're invading it's often 1v2 or even 1v3 meaning the host just turtles back while spawning an infinite amount of people to help them should somebody protecting them dies if you can't catch them while they're fighting a mob (invaders don't interact with npcs unless the host uses a special item that cancels that). Invaders can at least return home using an item, but if you're the one invaded it can be frustrating if the invader refuses to initiate vs you and turtles at the NPCs you need to advance. Invasions are only enjoyable when it becomes 2v2/3v3 or etc.  *Minor con* Game could use more sets to spice up the customization since personally I only find about 3 sets visually appealing although there at least is a decently large selection to choose from. Comes down to preference and again is a minor con if not a con at all depending on your taste/preferences.  *Minor con* Another minor con is it'd be nice if the game just had a straight up PvP arena you could queue for with matchmaking and such. Would make dueling easier and more consistent since one issue I have with dueling is that you have finite HP/FP (basically mana) and eventually have to rest or rejoin/die if in another world.   Pro or Con:  There's lore and such throughout the game, but it's not much of a hardcore story driven game like many other RPGs. Low amount of cutscenes with the game being more adventurous trying to figure out where to go and finding loot. This wasn't a con for me since I personally don't often play games for their story given I prefer PvP over anything.  Armor doesn't mean much as long as you're at least wearing a piece in each slot. No significant difference in tankiness between armor. If you prefer more variety in builds this could be a con since there's no big enough difference for speed vs tankiness being an option as long as you weigh less than 70. This also however means you can wear whatever you think looks cool giving the game's customization more variety.  Controller is highly recommended for this game. This is can be a con if you prefer kb+m. I prefer kb+m and adapted quickly to the game's controller and enjoy it a lot. You probably still could use kb+m, but I think you'd need to play around with the key binds first.

Well what can I say? I love Dark Soul and I had big expectations regarding the new installment. After a little bit disappointing Dark Souls 2, I was worried that Dark Souls 3 will be only a good game too. Thankfully, unnecessarily, because Dark Souls 3, the same as Dark Souls 1 is a masterpiece. Miyazaki delivers.  The game is beautiful, may be not a technological breakthrough, but the artstyle is godlike. Some of the views are magnificent. Artstyle wise it’s the best game on the market (IMO). The same goes for music. Orchestral score perfectly fits fights with huge bosses, and in my opinion, Dark Souls 3 has the best soundtrack when it comes to souls/borne games.   When it comes to the bosses, NPCs and gear, I must admit that I’m very pleased. The bosses feature great design, and some of the fights are one of the best in the series. It’s hard to judge their difficulty as I’ve been playing souls games for more than 600h. I love the fact that there’re so many references to Dark Souls 1, as it’s my favorite part of the series. Of course there’re references to other titles too, even to Demon’s Souls.   Moving to locations. They deliver too. The areas are varied and feature many hidden paths and secrets. Some of the areas are located off the beaten path and player will not find them if he/she’ll not look carefully.   Of course the game has its flaws. Probably the biggest one is the net code. Very often one will not be able to summon phantoms, and if they manage to do so the phantom/s may be lagging.  To sum up, the game is great and everyone who likes fantasy or looks for a challenging game should buy Dark Souls 3. For me the game is almost as good as the first installment, which I thought would be impossible (Dark Souls 1 is my favorite or the second best game of all time). I can only hope that the game will become even better with the upcoming two DLCs.   EMBRACE THE DARKNESS!

Nameless king was actually the most disappointing of the bosses in terms of difficulty. Last boss put up a bit of a fight but underhwelming. At this point we are going to start new characters and play goofy builds to attempt to make it more challenging on ourselves.  2. Overall the pvp is much better this time around, poise is still an issue but at least hits connect more often then not when they should. The largest problem here is the Sentinel and Darkmoon covanents, they needed a blue eye orb to punish sinners, or they needed the darkmoon faction being summoned when a sunbro was in trouble. WHEN the system works properly, you get some crazy invasion fights and i do love how chaotic they are.  3. Fan service is a little over the top. I loved Dark souls, but i didnt hate Dark Souls 2 as much as some, and almost all the fan service in this game in DS1, with very little to no mention of DS2. If the director gave up his role as lead developer to work on Bloodborn, he should of accepted the work and universe that was created in DS2 while he was busy. Instead this game basically ignores 95% of all content from that game, period. If i had to go further in depth, i would of prefered about 30-40% of the total fan service toned back and replaced with new and fresh that we havent seen. As cool as it is to have Andre as our blacksmith, thats a lost opportunity to be introduced to someone new.   Those are the 3 largest complaints i have. Overall i enjoyed the game, got my hours out of it, was money well spent and im sure the DLC will be good as always, just a few things that need to get patched up or reworked and this game could of been near perfect.

This is one of those times I wish steam had a sideways thumb, but oh well here we go  THE GOOD:  Beautiful levels, easily the best in the souls series and bloodbornes engine makes it only look better.  Interesting and unique looking enemy designs, usually appropriate to the area they're in.  Fantastic and memorable soundtrack compared to most of 2's.  Interesting bosses, most of them AREN'T big guys with a sword.  Soul Memory is gone! Thank GOD.   THE BAD:  Weapons have been slightly dumbed down from 2 and have copy/pasted movesets and sword arts, can no longer powerstance. Heavy weapons are too slow to punish both npc and player openings, and end up being inferior to swords, katanas or rapiers.  Enemies are really spastic, and do much more damage than any other souls game, dogs often phase through my raised shield and hit me, and not sensing that enemies half-second attack windup usually results in getting combo'd to death from full health.  Armor is now more about looks than protection and poise means absolutely nothing (they somehow made it more useless than 2's) which makes the spastic combo stunlocking enemies that much more of a more glaring issue.  Infusions are now borderline useless with the exception of strength or dex infusions due to them STILL keeping the system of having damage count against armor twice or more depending on how many elements your weapon is split into.  Boring, lifeless NPCs with quests even more cryptic than 1's, wave bye to that merchant, because you just accidentally sent them to their death because you didn't get to a point in another npc's questline first. Bugs bugs bugs, if its not a memory leak slowing your game to a stuttery crawl after a while, its outright random crashes, also having any sort of disconnect in your internet will kick you back to the main menu, resetting any potential boss fight you might have been in the middle of.   I really wanted to love 3, but it felt like it lost most of its charm in place of more bloodborne-y mechanics, and the optimization and bug issues just made it worse. First of all if like to end the first question that comes into your mind when you see this review, 'you have only played for 33 minutes so how can you write a review?'. I can write a review after spending this little amount of time in the game simply because i have played this games pre-desessors and can easily compared them.  The problems that i have personally found; Level Design Mechanics Creativity Structure Layout Lazyness, i can see how much you have stole from other games  Level Design. Dark Souls 3s level design feels rather unappealing in a lot of ways but is generally okay, there couldve been more love and creativity in a lot of areas and I feel like they really didnt try to fully develop the game the way that they should. The Catacombs are the catacombs, the demon ruins are the demon ruins, anor londo is anor londo, undead settlement is bloodborne. I can feel the lack of fun and the more pressure being put on them by Bamco. This game has no original concepts and pretty much all of its features are mimics and stolen ideas from the previous games. This game feels to me as if Dark Souls 1 and 2 were smashed together.  Mechanics The new mechanic to the game has been on my mind since i first saw someone play this game and what i dont understand is the point of it. Dark Souls had its way of limiting spam casting and that was from the number of times you can use them, this felt to me like what we selected was an old scroll which could only be used so many times before it was unuseable. Now its ben turned into the equilivent of mana... NO, NO, NO, STOP. Yo udont change something that had no problems and especially not to replace it for something that is used in almost every other game...  Furthermore The game is filled with untested, or generally missing mechanics, hyper armor is finnicky on a lot of weapons and poise is 100% absent. People keep testing to find out what it does and so far every single one has been disproven. Some enemies and some areas are flatout ruined by this missing poise  If a new souls player isnt interested in the PvP, hes better off playing Dark Souls 1 since its a more challenging and, in my opinion, a better designed game. The world design is so much more intertwined and strung together geniously, and while the game is a technical mess being one of the worst optimized games ive ever played on PC, I still dont mind it  Gameplay is intended to be much faster than previous entries, and feels very different from the more methodical gameplay of Dark Souls II - Roll's are faster and have a much cheaper stamina cost. Unfortunatley, this also means that certain enemies and bosses spam ludicrous attacks that force you to roll constantly and hope you wind up in the right spot. The Dancer in particular has this problem, and I often found that the best stratergy in this game is to cheese bosses out and try and make their harder phase as short as possible.  The mechanics also lack depth - Powerstancing is gone, and because rolling is easier, the punishing and methodical PvP from Dark Souls II is gone, along with the build diversity. There's no powerstancing, no I-Frames on backsteps, and less varied movesets. Most of the time, there is simply no incentive to do anything other than R1 in both PvP and PvE. PvP suffers the most here - why bother using an R2 when your R1 will also stagger, cost less stamina, and will, unlike the heavy attack, combo into a second hit.

Mimic Souls 3: This Door Opens on the Other Side  From's excuse to pit you against dozens of fat knights of all shapes and sizes (provided the only shapes available are fat) is back for a third serving.  My verdict on Dark Souls 3 is that it's inoffensive. It's basically boilerplate Souls. This feels like a yearly franchise formula game, loaded down with so much fan service references to Dark Souls 1 that it barely stands on its own. The game looks lovely but it's all just a bunch of ruined castles except for the village and library that feel taken from Bloodborne. The game is still the thematically goofy medieval fantasy pastiche we all know and love.  There's no level that's unplayably bad so Dark Souls 3 has Dark Souls 1 whipped thoroughly in that regard, and the level design is generally smarter than Souls 1's slapdash lazy design, but there's nothing especially good here. Just... BIG levels with three or four paths. Big for the sake of feeling big more than anything else.  The combat is an awkward mix of Bloodborne and Dark Souls, where the enemies are faster and you really aren't. Casters just don't stand a chance unless you reach the endgame just because the enemies hate you keeping a distance.  Worse still, poise is gone completely from the battle system. There is no way to tank a hit, every single enemy attack staggers you except for during rare heavy attacks where you have hyper armor. This drastically changes the pace of the combat where midgets waving their toothpicks around can easily stunlock you to death. This was always a Souls problem, but here, every single hit stops you cold and it is a net negative to the actual combat. It doesn't break it, but the game is worse for this decision.  The bosses average out to be pretty decent though.  All that aside, even an average Souls game is worth a shot, and there is nothing bad here (Well, the story is pretty awful, even by Souls game standards.), certainly not enough to turn you folks away from it. It's certainly more playable than Dark Souls 1, but not quite as good as Dark Souls 2. The only flaw is just that it's not all that interesting.  PvP is, as always, a cheesy imbalanced mess, but that's not changed a lick since Demon Souls.

Dark Souls III is an action RPG and the (supposed) final entry of the Dark Souls series by FromSoftware and a closure to Dark Souls and Dark Souls III. The game takes place in Lothric, the birthland of the fire, and allows the player to take control of an unkindled, an undead left to his/her endless sumbler. The unkindled is however soon awakened to embark on an important mission: finding the Lords of Cinder who still live in order to gather them to rekindle the First Flame and preserve the cycle.  From a pure gameplay perspective, Dark Souls III prides itself on taking the best elements from the previous games in the series (including Demon's Soul and Bloodborne) in order to craft the ultimate Dark Souls. The result is a game where aggression is slightly more important than the previous Souls and the player is tasked to find his/her way in far more complex and multi-layered areas. A feature back from the original Demon's Souls is a mana (or, better said, a focus) meter which is used both to cast spells and miracles and perform a weapon's special attack. Each weapon has its own focus move, which can either damage emenies in a certain fashion or perform some sort of crowd control. Special focus flasks have been introduced to regain focus: the player must decide how many flasks will be dedicated to health and how many to the focus. Another entirely new feature is a covenant, the Mound-Makers, that allows player to be summoned as mad, purple phantoms, who can either help or attack the summoning player as they see fit.  At the time this review is being written, Dark Souls III's meta-game is suffering from two major issues, however, which can affect both PvE and PvP: - The pose stat, which determines how many hits a character can whitstand before flinching, is NOT active, and therefore doesn't have any effect, on both the players and NPCs, althought it works for normal enemies and bosses. This makes wearing heavy armor kind of useless and strenght-oriented characters may have an harder time in PvE, since their swings are generally much slower and even the weakest enemies can stunlock them, if not careful - The potency of spells, hexes and miracles is somehow lower than in the previous games, unless the player uses all the rings and level up stats available to increase their power, therefore neglecting simple survivability, resulting in a weaker character in the long run. Pyromancies, instead, tend to be useful from the beginning of the game to its ending, especially the dark ones The main premise of Dark Souls III is about the player visiting a realm, Lothric, which is basically a crossroads between the different worlds and ages from the series. As such, the game features basically all the weapons, armors, NPCs and items the players have come to get used to through the various games, and at the same time tries to build an original experience for the final game. This kind of fanservice works wonderfully for most of the game, and the trip to Lothric really feels unique, but in other instances the pandering to the playerbase becomes REALLY obvious and many annoy some.  Another issue players may encounter in Dark Souls III is the rather obscure nature of the location of most NPCs and their related questlines, even by the series' standards. In this final game finding many NPCs and getting them to safety across the adventure requires either a good outside guide or A LOT of trial and error, as NPCS just won't appear at all or kill each other without the player being the wiser. This is especially problematic as basically half of them are also covenants leaders, meaning that losing them will cost you their covenant till the next playthrough.  It's safe to say however that any issues Dark Souls III may have doesn't change the fact that Dark Souls III not only is an incredibly solid and deep action roleplaying videogame that begs to be played more than once, but also a fitting end to a series

If you've never played a Dark Souls game before, this is a great one to start with.   PROS: First things first; I say its a good start, because it is the easiest in the series. The motions are fluid, if a bit restrictive (once you play it, you understand what i mean), the graphics are amazing, the game is REALY well optimized, and, true to form, this game will make you want to play more, even as you have your a$$ handed to you. Even the first boss is a nice tutorial into the game. The enemies are a for the most part predictable, but dont let that fool you. Almost every enemy has one move that looks like another, but attacks at different times, which can make parrying and dodging a bit difficult if you don't pay attention.   CONS: OFFLINE: One of the major cons per gameplay is the F***ING CAMERA! it can go haywire at the most inopportune moments, which in a game series known for difficulty, can screw you over fast. TIP: You can rely on the camera but always be aware of your surroundings. If the enemy goes out of lock and you can't see him, it helps to know where he probably is and to know where the escape routes are.   Poise is basically nonexistant in this game compared to the others. With the heaviest armor (tested with a few invasions for authenticity) you will still flinch with the weakest weapon hit. Armor is basically just to help get another 2-3% damage reduction, which admittedly CAN mean the difference between crouching over and dying and surviving with a couple hit points.  The worst aspect of this game is by far the anti-cheating system in place to 'protect' online players from hackers. You can only realy expect the anti cheating sytem to work on people who were HIT with hacked weapons or people who PICK UP hacked weapons that other players drop. Trust me, the anti cheating system is the BIGGEST F*** YOU to honest players I have ever seen. Oh yeah, and just so I dont forget to say it, the anti cheating system will PERMA BAN you. Not for a week, not for a month, not for a year, FOREVER.   Now although the cons might seem to outweigh the pros, I will still recomend this to people. The hackers, do seems to be dwindiling in numbers now that the game has been out for a while, and I personally love the game and gameplay far too much to just stop. My only suggestion is that, until FROM fixes the cheat problem to something much more manageable, THIS GAME IS NOT WORTH FULL PRICE. It is worth a buy , but wait till you can get everything for about 40 bucks (DLC INCLUDED). Once they fix the cheating system then I will say that it is worth full price.

This is a terrific Game. It looks like Dark Souls, it plays like Dark Souls, it sounds like Dark Souls.  But it's not Dark Souls.  Not litterally, at least.  Let's make a point here: this is a positive review.   This game is an absolut blast. I really enjoyed (and still am) enjoying this game, with all its glorious and shiny PvP, easy loot and non-punitive mechanics. But this is the biggest gripe I have with it:  It is fun.  When I think 'Dark Souls', fun is not the word I'd think of. Intriguing, Gothic, Dark, Depressive, Hard, Deep.   But not fun.  When I took care of Gwyn in the first title, I was exhausted. Of course, I was willing to take another trip in the NG+, yet I was terrified about having to go through all that sheer, magnificent pain and frustration all over again.  Dark Souls III, compared to that, is a stroll in the park.  And I am not talking merely about the raw difficulty of the thing: the depression, the choices I made, the people I saw dying; it all felt like I completed a unique, aestetic journey.  With Dark Souls III, I feel like farming, improving my stats, getting this or that weapon.   Plus, I had the dire feeling that FS had to throw cheap references to the older titles just to get its fanbase all moist. Don't get me wrong, I had my nerd boner up and hard in Anor Londo, but really, 10 square meters littered in dung? Is that it? Nice. but a cheap, really cheap vibe.  It's fun, it plays one thousand times better than Dark Souls 1 & 2, but it is kind of what Battlefield 4 is to Battlefield 2 (not litterally, because BF4 is utter ♥♥♥♥♥ while DS III is lovely <3).  I never thought I could enjoy a Souls so lightheartedly, and I can't really say wheter this is a good thing or not.  Long story short: if you are looking for a real Souls experience, fetch yourselves a Demon Souls or a Dark Souls, if you are looking for a slightly modern, less inspired Souls, get DS II.  If you are looking for a beautifully made, fast paced, way easier and bright Souls, get the third installment.  Praise die Sonne.

Dark Souls III is a fantastic game, Lothric is a compelling setting populated by unique and beautifully designed locales, ferocious and notoriously difficult monsters, and plenty of secrets in every nook and cranny. The game-play is everything you'd come to expect from a Dark Souls game, patient and skill-based, and with the addition of weapons arts Dark Souls III stands out from its predecessors as a finely polished experience. It has all the usual hiccups you'd expect from a Dark Souls game like questionable keyboard and mouse support, shaky online connection, and performance dips in certain areas, but none of it diminishes the genius of the game. While shorter than previous games Dark Souls III feels more dense and compact with lots to kill and lots to find.  You may be wondering from this gushing, glowing review why I am not recommending Dark Souls III. That can be answered with one short word:  Poise  Poise does not work, and according to From Software that is what they intended. If you don't remember in previous Souls games poise works as a statistic that determines how much damage you can take before your character is staggered/stunned. Heavier armours increase poise at the cost of speed, it only makes sense that a character wearing full Havels would shrug off the pathetic stab of an estoc. This is not so in Dark Souls III however. Poise DOES exist as a stat, in fact there are items that increase it such as the Wolf ring, who's only purpose is to increase poise. But, poise does NOTHING. You can wear the heaviest, strongest armour in the game and the weakest enemy you can encounter will stagger you. This ruins the game catastrophically. Sure heavy armour gives you great defence bonuses but at the cost of speed you can expect to be obliterated in pvp time and time again. This game will only support quick, agile fighters and that is unfair. I can understand why poise has changed, we have all been left infuriated by the Havel Moms and Giant Dads of yesteryear but destroying poise is not the way to solve that. It makes no sense for a man in rags wielding an estoc to be able to simply spam to death a man wearing Winged Knight armour. By removing/changing poise From have made half the items in the game worthless. According to tests, a higher poise has a miniscule effect on invincibility frames but otherwise has no effect in the game whatsoever. What's funny is, enemies have poise! You can strike them and they'll tank it. But we as players are not allowed it. I will gladly change this review should From correct the poise issue, but until then Dark Souls III is unfortunately (and it hurts to say this) the worst of the trilogy. I don't want to play an assassin, I want to play a slow, pondering tank, that is what I enjoy, but I simply can't, I will never win PVP that way. You may say git gud, but if git gud means changing my whole playstyle for something I don't enjoy then I'd rather stay bad.

Like the predecessors of the Dark Souls series, it's a gloriously detailed and gorgeous dark fantasy universe.  The singleplayer experience is hard, unforgiving. You are taught bare-bones basics of how to control your character, and then it's all up to yourself as the player to adapt and manage your own survival in a world where anything and anyone has the ability to kill you on the spot. But no matter how many times you fall, you'll never be granted death.  Be a Knight, Sorcerer, Archer, or a deprived miscreant void of any respectable equipment and test your mettle in a world where both Environments, Monsters, Undead, Bosses aswell as other Players are determined to make you a mental masochist. This is a world of suffering, and you'll realize this sooner or later.  Choose and make your OWN character. Choose your own weaponry. Make your own unique hero.  Multiplayer can be misleading upon purchase. Multiplayer is intertwined into the singleplayer experience. There's no multiplayer lobbies, hubs, or anything of the sort. Aslong as you have internet connection, you will be able to spot messages upon the ground that other players before you has left behind, become invaded by hostile players but also be able to summon other players to help you in -your- struggles.  Everything the game has to offer, must be explored and -found- in the game itself. There's no 'Press ESC and click on Multiplayer' kind of deal. All forms of luxury must be fought for, and obtained.  How immersive isn't that?  Dark Souls as a whole, is a dark fantasy universe with dimensions colliding into one another. In the world of most fantasy hack & slash games your hero can usually withstand blows that could demolish a building and act unphased by it all.   Only there's one major difference in Dark Souls in comparison to other fantasy games...  ...your Hero, is only human. Go ahead, get struck by a giant. Let's see if you stand tall afterwards. The covenants in this game are mostly PvP oriented so they all feel the same - even the Warriors of Sunlight (which was previously only based around friendly co-op) allows you invade someone along side another invader. The weapons and armour feel as if they were balanced only for PvP, despite it such a small portion of the game overall and how rolling was made to be ridiculously powerful in PvP, so kiss goodbye to poise and decent ranged weapons for the entire game.  To be a bit nit-picky, I really dislike the 'cloth-physics' that a lot of the armour has because I think it looks silly and it clips through too many objects. One last thing, why do the Souls games have the shields turned 90 degrees? It looks so stupid.

Here are the three reasons I wouldn't recommend Dark Souls 3  1. Core mechanics like Poise (a vital stat for almost every build in the game) have been stripped from the game leaving specific weapons with 'weapon arts' (a clear attempt at remaking trick weapons) with 'hyper armor' which makes them inherently superior to all other weapons for non-experienced players.  2. Useless mechanics like the Luck (literally only useful for item discovery and bleed build up) stat have been introduced when they were not needed.  3. PvP,unparriable weapons and Poise - Poise is completely gone,which cuts out many possibilities for builds.You get stunlocked by literally everything,even bare fists.This makes PvP just a fight between who can click r1 faster and makes PvE less and less fun as you progress(as I said above).PvP right now is just full of people who spam rapiers and daggers,stunlocking you to death,and people who spam heavy weapons(God only knows why they're now unparriable),stunlocking you to death aswell.  General unbalance - The absence of poise makes many areas in the game pretty frustrating(even for Souls veterans),but not only that. Conclusion:If just want this game for PvE and don't mind the 60 bucks price then go ahead,buy it,but if you wanted it for the PvP aswell then don't even bother considering it until these things are fixed,just download it cracked from a website,because right now I don't think they deserve the money the game costs.

Having 100% all 3 I can honestly say that this one is definitely my favorite. Dark Souls 2 left a very sour taste in a lot of people's mouths, and this love letter really helps wash that taste out. I'll admit there are a lot of issues that need fixing, but they really pale when it comes to how great this game is. The storyline is decent, a lot of old faces make returns, speculations are put to rest, and it feels like a Souls game. I was so worried it'd be Soulsborne, but I think it's a good thing having gone through NG++ to finish it off.   Like any Souls game you gotta beat it once to really start enjoying it, and god damn did I enjoy every hour. Well, outside of learning a few bosses, Nameless King, and a 10 hour grind for ears to finish off the Darkmoon, but still. The game does well to challenge you minus some loveable enemies who make their return, and it takes some getting used to that's for sure. It's also crazy how many builds are viable. I did a Demon Fist run and it was a blast. I did almost the entire NG++ with them, some PVP, and lots of CO-OP. If you play or plan on playing, then trust me. Get them, get them to +5, and then go do some jolly co-op on Vordt Of The Boreal Valley. It's stupid fun, especially with 3 people at the same time.  I'm no good at reviews, but I highly recommend the game. If you're a long time fan you'll really enjoy how refreshing the game is, and how well they've improved the game overall. Not to mention Fashion Souls has never been better. Tons of old armor for those looking to cosplay as well.

Dark Souls 3 is not only a worthy successor to the Dark Souls and Dark Souls 2, but skillfully combines all the lessons that FromSoftware has learned throughout the years with Demon's Souls all the way through Bloodborne. Veterans of FromSoftware's games will see references and mechanics from all the previous entries in the series, even Bloodborne. Combat is faster than previous Souls games, but no as fast as Bloodborne. For you Bloodborne players, get ready to unlearn the habit of relying on the regain system to get your health back. The environment and level design is much better than in Dark Souls 2, but they smartly stuck with the improved combat system from DS2 and improved it.Faster combat leadss into smoother combos and fancier moves, with Sword Arts being a cool new addition to the combat system.   As for performance, well that's a bit on the disappointing side. My GTX 760 struggled on the higher settings, and eventually the regular crashes forced me to lower the gnereal settings to Medium, and the Lighting setting on Low. Now it's running fairly consistent at about 40 fps and not crashing, which is good. I just had hoped that my 760 plus 16 GB of RAM and an AMD-FX 4130 processor would get closer to the 60 fps that I wanted. Hopefully the options will improve in the coming weeks, but it is a bit disappointing, if not unexpected.  Overall this game is excellent and despite some graphical issues and random framerate drops, this game is a solid conteder for Game of the Year. It's made my Best Of 2016 list already, and has a decent shot at a the Top 10 Favorites Games Ever list as well.  In short, this game takes all of FromSoftware's games and combines them into a mysterious and intruiging adventure. If May the flames guide thee.

I feel like this review needs more detail. I've spent 146 hours in Dark Souls 3. Specifically on 1 character. My character is NG+3 and I can annihilate bosses like it's nothing. Now let's see if I can't do the same for this review.  Dark Souls III as the third installment to the series had a lot to do to make it more than just another remake of the Souls series.   AI-Bosses: The very first thing I noticed in the game was the wide variety of random encounters (mini-bosses) as well as the actual boss battles being extremely fluid the first time you engaged them. The transformation stages of the bosses was a nice breath of fresh air for the Dark Souls battle equations. Even random enemies transforming was a shocker. AI and Bosses were my best experience.  Graphics: The graphics were breath-taking. Each area felt like a beautiful piece of pie that I could not wait to sink my greedy teeth into. I ate up the scenery so much. However, what I did not expect was the return of an area from Dark Souls 1. I bow down to FromSoftware. My nostaligia came back in waves.   Soundtrack: The soundtrack for Dark Souls III is possibly the best out of all of the souls games. Deep, intense and very immersive. Each area felt alive, hostile, and it helped lend to me wanting to explore more.  Combat PVE: The combat for PVE felt a lot more polished than in other games. Some weapons were considered extremely over-powered in the beginning of the game, but updates were pushed out to 'nerf' them. The weapons were so varied and tons were unique. Some weapons having been imbued with WoG shocked me. Amazing touches. The new Techniques were also very helpful in changing the way I played the game solo and with friends.  Combat PvP:  Here is where my primary focus is on the souls series. Hosting fight clubs, Invasions, and being invaded just to send them home crying. The combat is extremely fluid. It feels more like a dance now with the Techniques rather than just a struggle. Shield Turtles need to be nerfed a little due to the fact you can infinitely hold your ground with a greatsword, other than that, flawless combat. Magic finally felt viable in PvP. Bows, finally felt viable in PvP. Each weapon has its own unique use now that the other 2 games had problems fleshing out into the PvP aspect.  Overall: With the amount of time I have spent in this game, both in PvP and PVE, I would easily rate this game a 9.5/10. Your time will not be wasted.... Unless, you are afraid of dying a few times. And a few times after that.

This is a Dark Souls game through and through. Everything about it was designed with Dark Souls 1 fans in mind. It's immensely difficult but extremely satisfying when you actually succeed. As with any proper souls game there's dozens of ways to approach he scenario and the environments are beautifully crafted by From Software's team. The game's combat is second to none this time around. There isn't a game on the market that competes with Dark Souls III in terms of combat. As I mentioned there are MANY throw backs to Dark Souls 1 in this game all over the place. You find the lord vessel and Andre of Astora right within the first hour of the game. The bare essentials are there at Firelink Shrine as always and it's more homey than ever.   Exploration is rewarded always, unlike with other Souls games this one always will reward you for roving outside where the direct path lead. In order to go forward often times you have to go back, which I love about Dark Souls. However if you don't enjoy difficulty in video games don't purchase this. You'll die over, and over, and over again. At times you'll wonder where you're supposed to go and other times you'll want to quit altogether because you're so frustrated. But believe it or not I consider this a good thing. Because that brutal difficulty makes actually defeating your enemies that much more rewarding.  If you enjoy the Souls series this is a must buy!
