Dark souls 3 is a perfect game for anyone who's up for a challenge. A real challenge. Other games hold your hand through them and guides you, what dark souls does is something else. They give you some ♥♥♥♥, throw you in a pithole and then leave you there to handle things on your own.  Dark souls have always had varying and beatiful environment and this game nails it. The lightning is good, the surroundings look good, the sounds are amazing! And the soundtrack. The soundtrack is fkn amazing!  Many different weapons, all kinds of weird ♥♥♥♥ like dual-wielding two hammers who's bigger than yourself. All the weapons are incredibly good designed and looks astonishing! The animations are really smooth and look very real.   The PvE in this game is amazing! The bosses are really cool and some are really REALLY hard and some are actually dissapointingly easy. They are all very different frome one another. The amount of bosses isn't that much, Dark souls 2 have MUCH more bosses, but dark souls 3 is more like quality over quantity which I prefer.  The voice acting is good. It's nothing impressive but they keep to the dark theme which just fits perfectly.   And then there's PvP... I love it. PvP is the only thing I do now in the game now that I've completed the game two times. PvP has its ups and downs. What makes pvp slightly bad in this game is not the pvp itself, but the players. The constant ganking. When I invade a world I'm aware that it should be a hard time for me to beat the host, but not like this. When 4 people just hide and wait for an invader to invade and then gank the ♥♥♥♥ out of him, that destroys the purpose to invade. Thanks to this I never ever invade anymore since it's hopeless 'cause the game priorities the hosts with friends so there will almost allways be 2v1, 3v1, 4v1. In some very few cases I invaded a lone host which turned out to be really fun, but that only happened 3-4 times under my entire experience with ds3. But, there's an amazing side to the PvP, and that is the fight clubs. In some areas it's very popular to set up fightclubs, where the host watches and summons people to the fightclub where you fight other players in a duel. Duels have community-made rules which I love! I Love Dark Souls 1 and 2. They are the essence of what made me the person I am today.  But this one... I just hate it with every fiber of my body. It's absolutely horrendously designed, and has the worst balancing I have ever seen. Enemy designs are bland and boring, and the entire game is grey and uninspired looking, like an action rpg version of Modern Warfare 2.    Even the lore is boring, uncreative (practically copy and paste from the first two games) and barely even existing. I'll give you an example:  Yhorm. What happened to him? Never explained, but he knows Siegward for some reason.  That's it. More is never mentioned or hinted at.    Dark Souls 3 Feels like a horrible port of Dark Souls 1 assets to the Bloodbourne engine, and it plays and looks that exact same way. The speed of the Bloodborne gameplay with Dark Souls weapons and armor just don't work together. As a proof of that, they even had to remove poise.  Yes, that's right. Dark Souls 3 has no poise. It has the STAT poise, as in, you can get points in poise, but they only affect VERY, VERY CERTAIN BUILDS, and only if you use a weapon that has hyper armor frames in it's attack pattern, extending said frames, and also giving you some kind of roll hyper armor (?) that is almost completely useless, due to rolling giving you invincibility to begin with.   But no, poise does NOT affect your poise (Kind of ironic, isn't it?), and it hurts the game very, very badly, making heavy armor completely useless, due to the way this game calculates defense (you get your major amount of defense from simply wearing a piece of armor, not WHICH piece of armor). You'll know what I mean as soon as you try fighting against 5-8 enemies at once (who just so happen to HAVE poise and way too much of it too, a dinky small dagger wielding enemy sometimes has the poise of a Havelmonster back in DS 1 and 2) in this game without a weapon that gives you hyper armor. And this game LOVES to just enemy spam the sh*t out of you to compensate for how easy and boring it is.   So yeah, have fun getting stunlocked in Havel armor by dagger wielding little sh*ts, while they barely flinch when you hit them with your Ultra-Greatsword. And even IF you stagger them, most of the time they just continue attacking MID STAGGER ANIMATION. That means they will most of the times completely ignore that they are staggered and cancel out the staggering and keep attacking. Like some chum in a fighting game doing a combo breaker, but these mobs can just spam it, while you don't have such a thing. Great, huh?  Let's get to the bosses.  Boss fights are the only fun thing in this game, and the Bosses themselves are the only interesting and worthwile about this game.  There's only one problem.  They are too easy. Compared to the mobs in this game (and the enemy spamming) the bosses are ridiculously easy. Some of them can even be stunlocked with fast weapons, because they have no poise either! This should not be the case. The bosses should be HARDER then fighting the common mobs around the boss area, but they are not. Whether this is a problem with the strength of the mobs or the weakness of the bosses, this should NOT be the case.    As far as I can tell, It's like FromSoft tried to make a Bloodbourne 2, screwed it up, and then decided to throw Dark Souls assets into it at the last minute, figuring 'Eh, they'll buy it if it has Dark Souls written on it'       Overall, this game does one thing and it does it very well:  Remember me of the good old times of Dark Souls 1 and make me play that one again instead.

I'm not sure why PC players are complaining about the PC version not working. This game runs gloriously on PC, and with the PS4 controller I don't feel handicapped by keyboard/mouse because lets be honest, keyboard/mouse for Souls is like playing the Deprived class on heroin. (For those who don't know, it's essentially the hard game's 'hard mode.') . Moreover for those having FPS/Crashing issues, I can't say I've experienced anything other than flawless gameplay. I have not experienced a single crash, FPS stutter, or anything of the like. The only complaint I have is the summoning system, but that's typical of Souls games.   I've spent the last two days (about 5 hours a day) dying, falling off cliffs, getting rekt by ambushes, and cursing vehemently at my computer screen for allowing me to die. I've loved (HATED) every second of it. (PLEASE KILL ME.) No, really. Dark Souls III is (in my opinion) one of the best in the souls series to date. Unlike Dark Souls II I actually find myself caring about the NPC's and the stories they tell. From Soft really got back to the old school Dark Souls I feel, and the game plays wonderfully. Similarly, a problem in DS II where you'd get insane frame rate lag when rendering large objects has been resolved. I don't think I've dropped below 60 FPS since I first booted up the game.  The boss battles do feel a little...easier? That's not to say they aren't fun fights, but they definitely dialed back the difficulty of bosses (from what I can gather.) In contrast, I feel like they really buffed the every day average joe monsters in the game. Hell, you'll fight giants and tag team NPC's similar to Black Knights that aren't even real bosses, but they will give you a run for your money every time, and they don't pull any punches.  Overall, I'd give it an 8.5/10. It's by no means perfect, as no game ever is, but it is definitely a must buy for the avid Demon Souls/Dark Souls fan. I honestly don't regret buying the season pass either, simply because I know I will put in a lot of hours towards completion. (As many hours as I can while working a full time job.) If you love the Souls game, you'll love Dark Souls III. If you're new to the series, let me just say a few things:  1) PRAISE THE SUN. 2) PREPARE TO DIE. 3) YES YOU CAN FALL OF THE LEDGES. 4) DON'T TRY TO FACEROLL. 5) WELCOME TO HELL.

Heavy armor's main advantage was Poise, allowing you to withstand hits without flinching, or slightly so untill you're staggered. Clerics, Sorcerers, Pyromancers and Warriors alike, were all hindered by this change to the 3rd installment. To this degree, you might as well as start off deprived and play through the entire game as is, or atleast use the Master's attire because armor reduction does jack all. I have spent countless of hours on the first two souls games and so i was really, really hyped for this one. Unfortunatly, the game was quite a... frustrating disapointment to me.  Truth is, this is a pretty good game. I mean, graphics and artistic directions are just gorgeous, the musics, the theme, the design choices, it's challenging. So yeah, quite the thing you expect from a souls game.  Although, to me the game was more of a Bloodborne with shields rather than a Dark souls 1-ish. Which is fine, but...  Well, to me, what really made the two firsts game shine was that, even if the game was difficult it offered the player so many variety on how to tackle the challenges that, it felt rewarding doing choices and improvising builds. And these builds determined how the game would flow and react. I've never been good in souls games, but i found myself really confortable with heavy tank builds that let me actually soak attacks rather than having to nervously dodge everything at perfect frame and so i was happy with that, because even if not good i could beat things and felt clever finding right items for my playstyle.  But here, you really feel that the choices design where made to create a more dynamic experience where enemies will be fast and agressiv and where you have to timely dodge attacks in order to do a thing. And so most of the build variety was nerfed in order to promote a more specific type of gameplay that every mobs tend to follow. To be more precise, parry and poise are now quite uneffective, if not pointless. Mobs will usually overload you with attacks that remove almost all your stamina bar in 1or 2 hit, and most of the trash will stagger you if you get a few hits, even with Havels set and rings on. How dodge rolls work is that it is way more effective to spam dodge, since the stamina recover extremly fast with almost no recovery on dodge, that you have little to no need to actually parry rightly expect for a few boss attacks. I've been using ultra great swords and the like at first, being a fan of huge strengh builds, but i could barely hit a thing without being staggered by any enemy. So i switched on straight swords since most of them have better range and damage output than some heavy weapons.  It could have been just that but, on my experience, the game was also a technical mess. The camera was horrible, getting obstructed in everything it could while locked on an enemy, getting me stuck in small background elements mapped everywhere. The lock distance felt way too short and broke for almost no reason when i was passing behind small items or behind walls. It also broke when moving backward sometimes, when passing a door or like, climbing a stair. Got killed a lot by mimics because it couldn't follow its movement around me either. Enemies spotted and attacked me through walls where weapons would bounce against. In fact, most of the time my attacks would fail because i happened to hit a small part of background behind me. It felt greatly unprecise and clunky. Never had these issues in the first two souls, or at least not as often as i did in this one. Speaking of lock on, Arrows and projectiles missed target almost everytime if it was moving just a tiny little bit, firing completly out of direction. And even while aiming with R1, arrows would just pass through things sometimes due to some hitbox shenanigans.  The game added a bunch of new mecanics like sword arts that use mana but, i almost never used them in PvE because by the time i was casting them i usually got hit and canceled/staggered, if not just doing too little damages to be worth their cost in time and mana.  I also found that the game was really hard to read. Most of the backgrounds are overloaded with details and even if most of the paths are straights, enemies were pretty hard to spot since they are in almost the same tone of everything around and don't always move or behave in a way they're easy to identify (when they don't just not appear at all due to some culling problems). I found myself really spending a lot of time in most of the early area just to look around things because there was simply to many things to look at everywhere.   So... yeah, after a bunch of 40 hours and a NG+, even if the story and the ending are really, really good, to me the game wasn't what i expected to be the climax of the serie.  It's not bad, it's just... It doesn't feel like a souls to me.  It's worth noticing that i played the game in offline mode, mainly due to the hackers issues there has been going, though. (yeah, steam don't understand that people may use offline mode sometimes :/)

This game feels like a greatest hits collection of the souls/borne series.   Combat is air tight.  The world is atmospheric and vast, with almost no impossible space (Think houses in skyrim, tiny on the outside, huge inside. None of that crap).  Weapons have been refined to make every single weapon viable and fun to use.  The armor system is designed in such a way to make any set a solid choice. Enemies are varied and truly deadly while being fair. The bosses are incredible again. Gone are the days of Dark Souls 2 bosses where every single one is 'Large humanoid with big weapon'. The PVP netcode has been improved substantially. The new Weapon Art system ads an entire new dimension to combat. 'Quality of Life' tweaks, like passwords for co op with friends, or improved item/wepon swapping.   This game took what worked from Dark Souls, and Bloodborne, and meticulously removed everything from Dark Souls II that was not fun to create a near perfect game.  I will now be judging all future souls/borne games according to this game. This should have been Dark Souls II.

I've yet to run into a scenario were I felt like getting better at the game wasn't the solution -- i.e. finding glitches. Because of the difficulty of the game , when you beat a boss it feels super rewarding and as you get stronger you feel like a huge bad ♥♥♥ because it wasn't to long ago that you fled from the enemies that you just destroyed. I would love to see From Software exmpand on the co-op / pvp game play as it currently feels a bit shallow, still fun just feels like it could be more. I am a big fan of the first Dark Souls and it saddens me that this is not the game I wanted as a sequel.  The original DS was supportive of a very calculated approach to fights, sadly and, I believe due to influence from Bloodbourne, this is no longer the case. Where previously you could keep your shield up and time your attacks you're know faced with unrelenting enemies that have combos capable of wearing you down and then beat you to a pulp. This is also a problem in bosses, that this time have a lot more stamina and a few one or two-hit kill attacks., making them incredibly more difficult to beat and far less fun - I really felt like I was losing unjustly and that made me want to give up and just summon help, killing a fundamental part of the enjoyment.  A solution to this overpowered attacks problem could be found in armour reinforcement, but that is now gone, reducing your ability to 'bulk up' before trying a tough fight to levels and (far less significant) weapon upgrades.  The game's NPCs are also far less interesting and diverse and their appearances are very poorly spread out.  From about a point early in the game the best tactic starts to be 'go up to enemy and spam quick attack so it can't move' - this had no place in a Souls game.  If you're considering buying this game I'd say: just go play the first one.

This review will be updated when appropriate: Cons: Game was released in a buggy state. Crashing near bonfire was running rampart. (fixed) Literally, bonfire was the hardest boss in the game. Optimization is absolute worst. (not fixed) Then FromSoft started banning legit players, just because. who knows. (not fixed) Some of the Covenants like Farron and Blue Sentinels don't work, they simply don't summon you. (not fixed) Poise is broken and doesn't work. (not fixed) PVP balance is absolute worst. First souls game where 5vs1 is acceptable and no amount of 'getting good' will save this. (not fixed) Longswords and rapiers are absolutely broken and OP. (not fixed) Many amazing gameplay elements that Dark Souls 2 introduced are gone: No small white/red stones. If you kill boss - co-op and pvp(forceful invade) in that area is gone for good until NG+. No more indicator what maps are popular for pvp. Slow, methodical and tactical approach of Dark Souls is gone in favor of fast pacing Bloodborn, were enemies hit like characters from Mortal Kombat or Tekken. Less spells, less pyromancies, less miracles. Pyromancy depends on sorcery and faith this time, which abolishes whole purpose of this school. Faith spells are absolutely worthless. Sorcery is legit, but struggles unlike DS1/2.  Pros: Amazing, atmospheric, bleak world in best Souls traditions. Good, but somewhat incoherent and hard to follow story. Interesting NPC's with their unique questlines. No more Havel-Mages from DS2.  Original Bosses. Probably the hardest Souls game. Good music. True successor of Dark Souls 1 which brings nostalgia like tears from onion.  TL:DR: Whether you should buy this title mostly depends on do you prefer technical aspect or lore/core/world aspect. Personally, I think game has too much of Bloodborn in it. Even some assets are straightforward copy-paste job from Bloodborn. Still, i'd wait until all issues are fixed and PVP is balanced, and buy only then.

Its so good. Really. This is shaping up to be best souls game yet, and I consider DS1 to be my favorite game of all time. The combat feels complete with the arts system, and it adds a whole new layer of strategy to the mix. The world design is as good as Bloodborne. Much like Bloodborne, the weapons in this game feel very visceral, and the blood effects are really well made. The graphics are obviously impressive.  There are only two complaints I have about the game, and those are the story and the difficulty.  The story takes the route of DSII, in that your character is considered some 'chosen one' by every member of the cast right from the beginning. This is something that DS1 perfected, giving you a sense of accomplishment as the people you met previously realize that you aren't one of the many who inevitably give up, but are a persistent enough player to best the game. I don't feel like that here. The Dark Fantasy world set up in the game suffers a bit by this weird-trustworthiness you seem to have without really accomplishing much.  My other complaint is the difficulty. I have died maybe 3 times in the 2 hours i've played the game so far. I'm not playing a specialized build (just a knight with the life ring and a higher emphasis on dex), but i've beat every boss in one try. That isn't souls-like. It could be a number of different things, maybe i just happened upon a really good setup, or i'm carrying over experience from other souls games, but it doesn't feel like it. I got ♥♥♥♥ed in DSII, like really bad. I was expecting to get destroyed in DSIII, but it hasn't happened yet.  The optimization is on par with SotFS. I haven't had any problems at all, although its worth noting that I am using an XBone controller. I reccommend a controller if you're looking to play any souls game.  All in all, the positives far outweigh the negatives on this one. Dark Souls III is undeniably worth your money, and it is an extremely well put-together game. If you're a returning souls fan, or are looking to get into the series, DSIII is a great experience.

The worst of the Dark Souls bunch Take every complain about Dark Souls II, and make it worse. Take every good thing about Dark Souls II and take it away.  -Universe-  New lore ? Nah, let's make dark souls I all over again. They squeeze everything they can from the first game just so they don't have to make new things. You litteraly fight Artorias and the Asylum Demon all over again. And the final boss is basically Gwyn with the exact same moveset and music. The ONLY difference being he can't be parried. New blacksmith ? Nah, let's juste copy past Andre of Astora. New Fire Keeper ? Nah, let's take the maiden in black from demon's souls, and put a tiara on her face.  It could pass for fan service, but it's litteraly the entire game. It's like the dead or alive of Dark Souls, litteraly.   Area wise, it's even worse. The game is litteraly Dark Souls I... Most of the game is juste castle and ruin, exactly like the beginning of Dark Souls I, then, they copy past Anor Londo in the game. Wich give you access to another ruin and another castle... It's that bad.  People complained about fighting too many humanoids and not enough monsters in Dark Souls II, they will be happy, for the game contain the whooping number of 3 'monster' bosses, including... A skeleton but giant, Gwyndolin but with slime, and a dragon wich you can one shoot.  People complained about having only Majula as inerconnectivity in Dark Souls II ? They heard you, now, even the hub isn't connected to anything. I searched for at least half an hours before realising that you litteraly had to teleport to reach the first ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ level. Remember how areas where complexe and with multiple path in Dark Souls I ? Kiss it goodbye too, by the way.  -Gameplay-  You liked powerstancing and dual wielding in dark souls II ? Kiss it goodbye. They added a weapon art system, wich basically replace the L2 by a special attack, but that's all, and it's not even used in dual wielding, you have to two-hand your weapon.  PVP-wise, it's the worst it could possibly be. The covenant are boring, you have the invader, the invader in the swamp, the invader in anor londo, the blue sentinel, the blue sentinel but better and the sunbros. And the invader who can be killed by other invaders. Invaders are usually outnumbered, and they have their estus divided by two, when you want to level your Mound Maker (the covenant where the invaders and the host wants to kill you) they specifically chose worlds where there is a lot of phantoms, so everyone can kill you.  But it's not all, not only the convenant are horrible, but the poise is gone, letting the meta be overwhelmed by straight sword R1 spam.  The game is faster, wich is, IMO, a good thing, you can compare it to bloodborne, wich also make it easier than the two other souls. You can drink estus litteraly during a combo, and the roll as an incredible amount of i-frame. The bosses can also be staggered by regular attacks (looking at you, abyss watchers), or they can be parried into oblivion (looking at you, Gundyr).  With the weapon art system, you would think it allows some crazy weapons, right ? Nah. Remember the straight sword that turns into a whip ? Nothing like that. You just get the usual weapons you can expect, and they most of the time share the same weapon art. Curved sword have a spinning attack, and the boss curved sword as the exact same spinning attack but with pretty clouds... And the same moveset. Artorias sword has the exact same moveset as other greatsword, but the weapon art allows a jump instead of a dash, and a double spin instead of a single spin.  -TL DR-  Basically, it's pure fanservice, who forget everything good that was instaured in previous titles, such as transforming weapons, powerstance, actual dual wielding, interesting NG+. However, it knows how to take advantage of previous title to copy paste bosses and entire areas into the game, as well as putting the same lore all over again. Remember Gwyndolin ? Well, he is a boss in this game too. Remember Priscilla ? Well they cloned her so she is covenant leader (from a covenant wich was already in DSI, because making new covenant would be complicated).  After all that salt, even if the game litteraly spit on most people expectation of the 'last and best of the soulborne serie'... It's still a good game. Not as good as the rest, but a good game on it's own. However I still would recommend it if you didn't get into the soul serie, because you would not see the lack of lore (because the old lore would be new for you), and the game is easier, so you would suffer a lot less. However, be prepared, for the game is really fast compared to the others, so going back too any other game except Bloodborne will be really painful (especially regarding the estus, wich is infinitely faster and allows you to move while drinking, unlike in the I and II).

After killing a mob of cloaked miscreants I wandered into a large open area with a petrified warrior with a sword stuck through his chest. I pull it out, because nothing back could happen by poking around a immense and fierce looking warrior. Seconds later he animates and comes back to life, as he pulls the mass of his body up and corrects his posture, I tremble in fear and the anticipation of imminent death. I thought well ok, he is a big guy so Ill just roll around his and run circles around him, similar to the trick of defeating the King in Dark Souls 2. Nope, every timeI roll to avoid his fearsome spear he throws out another one and impales me with his spear, lifts me 20 feet in the air and tosses me like a rag doll across the arena. Death.  This is the ONLY game where dying repeatedly and failing repeatedly is ridiculously fun. Every time I die I think, touche, good fight but I will be back. Bosses in DS3 MUST be respected and treated accordingly. They are fearsomely aggressive and have ten fold the strength of you. On my fifth attempt to get him I got his health to half and he began to transform into some ungodly abomination, if only I had the words to describe this. My health was a little sliver and I was out of Estus flasks and unable to heal myself. I thought well **** im done, at least I can just charge and try to learn his behavior and attacks. As I hack away at the demon, and doge and roll from his attacks, his health lingers at just a sliver and we both face the possibility of imminent death. As he swings his arm at we I roll in and my swing connected, ending the battle..  A RUSH of adrenaline flooded me and I began pumping my arms and beating my chest. Never has a game caused me to celebrate in an excessive manner. My neighbours must think Im crazy as they hear me screaming and pounding.   If you have played Dark Souls 1 or 2 you will adore this game, it takes all the best elements of gameplay and refines them, shaping them into a new and perfected style. Similar to bloodborn, you are much more agile and fights are faster and more aggressive. I sunk 300 hours into Dark Souls Scholar of the First Sin on Xbox One, had three characters and would farm the giant memory/level to farm souls and acheive godly strength. As soon as i booted up this game, I quickly realized that the game is MUCH more stingy on souls, which is a good thing and makes the game more challenging.  TECHNICAL ISSUES?@! When I saw all the negative reviews I started to panic. I thought please god no please let me play it. As I booted it up, anticipating some error message or crash, everything worked, The game DOES have frame rate issues, and I think a lot of people not being able to play might not have sufficient hardware on their PC to accomodate the game. I run it at medium settings on a laptop (MSI -3.6ghz CPU/GTX950 GPU) and get probably about 20 FPS. And honestly it doesnt affect me in a huge way. Yes it is annoying but dude this game... Id probably play it with 5 FPS and be happy. I havent played much so I will update this review so it is more comprehensive and detailed.

Not nearly as good as sex.  Just as diffcult as marriage. ---------------------------------------------------------------  Dark Souls 3 is my favorite game to come out since Fallout 4. In general it is a diffcult game to recommend to impatient or lazy gamers. The game asks you to figure it out on your own....which is both a blessing and a curse. I really recommend a new player watch some walkthroughs on youtube of the beggining areas to both learn the basics as well determine if you would even want to play this game.   It is extremly hard at first, but once you become comfortable it is hands down the most rewarding RPG you can play. Every single weapon in the game can be made to be good - even your intial weapon. But new weapons aren't just cosmetic or stats upgrade - it becomes about movesets and if you like how it attacks.  Nothing is given to you, not even the story. It is up to you to figure it out. This game will punish your carelessness and reward exploration. The map designs are incredible and shortcuts can be unlocked in very logical and neat ways. The enemy design so far is the best I have seen in any souls / bloodborne game. Each enemy has diffrent movesets and classic enemies like mimics will suprise you with completely new tactics and attacks.  Unlike almost every game out there, boss battles are special. The sense of accomplisment and item reward is incredible. I have read new players spending hours on the first boss which can be a daunting experience. But always understand the game is trying to teach you to 'git gud'. Once you become good and the early areas are easy. Then comes the traps, new enemy attacks, strange boss battles that have you challenging your wits as much as your timing.   On a final note I will say this. I hated Dark Souls 1 when I got it. I hated Dark Souls 2. I disliked Bloodborne......but then when I was bored of other games I jumped back into Dark Souls 2....I learned to like it. I started to get quite good, I watched some video's explaining the stats. Then I tried Bloodborne again and I finally beat it and even did alot of the challice (optional) dungeons.  Without a doubt this game is not for everyone. I hated this type of game intially....now it sits proudly in my Top 5 game series of all time next to civilization, fallout, gta, and elder scrolls.   If you can get past the STEEP intial learning curve....it is amazing experience and possible the most amazing hand crafted worlds.

Straight up took me 2 hours to beat the tutorial boss, and I had beaten NG+7 on DKS and DKS2. 10/10.   On a serious note, everything that Dark Souls and Dark Souls II built up, this game perfected. The system for spell casting with charges on spells was replaced with a mana system, and I really enjoy it. The rolling and parry system were replaced with a roll system that is a bit weirder with the 'I' frames coming in towards the end of the roll, and the parry system now has you parry at the start of the animation rather than at the middle. It took a while to get used to, but I feel like its better than Dark Souls and Dark Souls II's rolling and parry system. The feeling of the game is very atmospheric and you will be presented with gorgeous view after gorgeous view. The graphics are great, and the setting of the game reminds you of places you have been before such as    Firelink Shrine and Anor Londo    while taking a new perspective of each area. The character creation system is just as if not more deep than the other games as well. Overall, while I have not finished the game I think that this is the best in the souls series.   TL;DR Pro: Great soundtrack Pro: Great visuals Pro: Much 'cleaner' gameplay Pro: Just as many memes Pro: Has Onion Knight Bro Pro: Brutal Difficulty  Con: The changes are hard to get used to Con: 3 stupid ♥♥♥ god damned poison swamp areas Con: Brutal Difficulty.  RATING: 9.5/10

(Disclaimer: This review is aimed towards those considering paying for this game, not the people who already have bought it, because based on my interactions, they're nothing but blindly accepting sycophants who blame all the flaws of the game on the people playing it, and deny any criticism towards it as being bad at it. This is coming from a member of the Undertale fandom and a fan of the DkS 1 and DkS 2 to a slightly lesser extent)  At any rate, I tried to review this once before, and despite my valid complaints against it, I was immediately flamed for several hours by the aforementioned fanbase before I decided to delete it just to shut the meatheads up.  Dark Souls 3 (and indeed the series in general) is a series of rather grim and dark fantasy games from developer From Software, notorious for being difficult. Set in the final days of The Age of Fire, you are Unkindled, who's goal is to return the stray Lords of Cinder to their thrones in Firelink Shrine, and link the fire to perpetuate The Age of Fire. The game takes place in the hauntingly beautiful Generic Kingdom #873 whose name I'm not sure you ever find out, except for The High Wall of Lothric and Lothric castle, and despite progressing through the game to the Castle, I can't say for certain if that references the Prince or the Kingdom, or both.  To get graphics out of the way, they're nothing short of gorgeous. I'm running it on mostly maxed w/ my 980, and it's absolutely breathtaking the work they put into the game. When I first entered Irithyll of the Boreal Valley and witnessed the gorgeous view presented to you (with messages saying the same, of course) I was stunned.  The gameplay is something I can only describe as hack-n-slash. You're given a wonderfully diverse set of weapons, from daggers, swords and shields to cartoonishly large spiked maces and world-ending sized axes, who each come with a special weapon skill to use the Blue bar (FP) returning from Demon's Souls. Not only that but you can choose from a few different styles of magic. Miracles, a faith based school of holy magic. Pyromancy, self explanitory. Sorcery, you're stereotypical arcane magic based in Intelligence. Not only that but there is also an overarcing school, called Dark Pyromancies/Miracles/Sorceries, based on the AoTA sorceries in DkS 1 and Hexes in DkS2. There really isn't a whole lot you can't do with your character, even if you want to be the guy with the naked fatass character who goes around clocking people with fist weapons.  The story continues the tradition of never forcefeeding you more than you need to know, and some area's even leave you with more questions than answers (The Untended Graves being a prime example of this; A beautiful setting enveloped in darkness, more than that I won't go into for the reader's sake) Leaving you to piece together the background from the dialogues of somewhat rememberable characters and from the descriptions of items (such as boss souls)  Unfortunately that's where the good things I can say about it end. While I appreciated the Tough but fair rule that From Soft. made a key philosophy in Dark Souls, it was lost to a small-to-medium extent in Dark Souls 2, which wasn't unbearable. I talk about this because while it was lessened in 2, it was beaten to a pulp, shot in the face, and thrown in the river in Dark Souls 3 with some of the changes, most notably by adding a large amount of hyperactively aggressive monsters and the nullifying of Poise as a concept.  The first complaint is the most glaring when looking at the game through fresh eyes. A very good example of this the red-eyed sword and throwing knife guy in Catacombs of Carthus, or The Watchdog that you fight when heading to Road of Sacrifices from The Undead Settlement. Both are agile to an extreme degree, hyper aggressive and almost ridiculously strong where if you try to block and roll for an opening, you'll take massive damage from their seemingly infinite stamina, and if you try to attack them first, you'll take massive damage because while Poise does nothing for you, there are quite a few enemies who simply cannot be staggered unless you manage to get several hits in, in quick succession, without your limbs being used to decorate the surrounding area, which means even if you go middle of the road between blocking and attacking first, taking your time and picking your shots, chances are the moment you land a hit on them, the monsters will land several on you, depleting a fair bit of your health. Case in point, the winged knight in Lothric Castle, just before the twin dragons. I did my best to evade his attacks while trying to take shots where it would seem safe to get them, only to land 1 or 2 hits and have a fair bit of my health deleted.  Going from that into the topic of Poise, it only technically exists, and by technically I mean that it is a stat on your screen, nothing more. In the first 2 games, Poise was a stat determined by armor that decides how easy you are to stagger when attacked. While it seemingly worked A-OK in 1/2, it looks like they decided to try and fix something that wasn't broke by making poise pointless and using it for something that I'm convinced is imaginary, hyperarmor, which supposedly makes you unable to be staggered mid-to-late swing, but even reading up on it, equipping the heaviest armor I could, I was still staggered in 1 shot by any monster I tried to go up against.  To summarize (tl;dr) Dark Souls 3 is a beautiful, sometimes very fun game with very high points because of the story and the beauty of it, it also has very very low points because of the fact that they let their reputation of difficulty get in the way of also making it not a totally frustrating mess. While it's not always obnoxious, I would say more often than not. That being said I will be playing it completion against better judgement, and I would only recommend it if you're okay with the above, or a diehard fan of From Softs work.      Let loose with your flaming, fanboys. I'm not indulging you any further than I already have ☀

It could be me just clinging on to the past, because I LOVE all these old boss fights and areas, O&S are the best. The thing that kinda pisses me off about this game is that From was clearly aiming for a wider audience, by making TV advertizements and such. This means that so many people are being pulled into the 3rd game with no prior experience, and just rage quitting because they don't understand what to do. One of my friends refuses to even try the old game because he says it 'sucks', even though he has never actually played it. So if you are someone who wants to try out Dark Souls and thinks they should get the 3rd first, don't. The games are so much more satisfying to play sequentially and the difficulty makes a lot more sense that way.

This is now the fourth version of my review. After completing the game and exploring practically every nook and cranny, I guess I can write something more thorough. *Warning: mild spoilers ahead*  Positives  +looks and runs like a dream at a constant 60FPS on max everything (CPU: core i5 6600 GPU: GTX 9604GB). Optimised ftw! +gorgeous game world that is brilliantly connected (at least within the same level, the shortcut potential within a level is excellent). +Excellent combat system, best yet +Extremely challenging and varied mobs. I mean, the mid-level mobs are often harder than the bosses, so were a great challenge.  +brilliant choice of weapons +Fashion Souls is back and better then ever. I miss that desert priestess outfit from DS2 tho so no Sexy Souls +Hallowing is now practically welcomed +no more freaking penelty for dying too often (DS2 would sap your health bar after every death) +Wondeful atmospheric boss music +levelling up past 100 to become OP isn't such a hassle anymore as jolly co-op is a piece of pie and souls are earned like you're Donald Trump. +Firelink Shrine is filled with cool homies you meet along the way and it's fun filling out your crib with undead mates. +Killing the Firelink maiden again and again without repercussion :D :D :D  -frequent crashes -extremely laggy co-op (sometimes) with people 'floating' as they walk' -Freaking hackers!!! -game world not as well connected as Dark Souls 1 (which was essentialy one long loop with crazy shortcuts from the beginning of the game to the end). DS3 relies too heavily on bonfires which... -Are stupidly placed. There is one instance near the end of the game when you light a bonfire and literally seconds later, walk into another. Did this slip by quality control or what? -bosses, with the expection of two, are absolute cake-walks and can be done on the first try -PvP is a little broken and only Dark Souls vets will get any joy as gank squads are pretty common -New game plus is a broken joke. The enemies don't really scale to any meaningful difficulty, so you'll be a true god amongst the ashes. Darks Souls 2 did new game plus really well. -Most of all, this is the easiest, most linear Dark Souls yet. I mean, I took my time with it, I really did but I still finished it without having to summon any help, except for the second last boss.  Ultimately, it's still a Dark Souls game and is approximately 1000x more enjoyable than most other games. Can't wait for whatever comes next. 9/10 (because no more Sexy Souls :()

Edit: Having now completed the game, I will say that Dark Souls 3 is a repetitive, easy and short copy-paste cash-grab. The castle/cathedral environment is repeated ad-nauseum and even the same enemies are re-utilized throughout the game. Most bosses were easy enough that I didn't get to see their complete moveset. Very disappointed at the moment, its the first souls game were I put down my controller after finishing the game instead of immediately starting NG+. Also, people online are saying that NG+ has absolutely nothing new besides a few +1 or +2 rings. Recommend you wait for a bundle with the game+DLC or buy on sale, its not worth full price at the moment.   I'm happy to report I experienced no crashes on my gaming laptop. Bugs at the moment include summon/phantom animation, and a jerky framerate. Gameplay wise, DS3 is a hybrid of DS1 and Bloodborne, with more emphasis on the Bloodborne elements IMO. Armored Core pls From Software) in the Souls trilogy (not including Demon's Souls and Bloodborne obviously because console exclusives), and boy, it is definitely as hard as always. Enemies are much more varied now than the typical large men with large swords in heavy armor of Dark Souls II, and their movesets are quite more complicated now. I did not try PVP extensively because of slow internet, but there are still NPCs which can invade you or be summoned to help you. (though I hear mage builds are less viable now)  Soundtrack is epic as always, and the sound design can be very atmospheric (hint: turn up the volume when you reach Irithyll Dungeon).   Story-wise, the game doesn't explicitly tell it to you in your face, but the background lore can be gleaned from tidbits in dialogue and item description so that you yourself can connect the dots.  If you like a challenge, get this game.

Dark Souls 3 is very much like previous entries of the Dark Souls series. The graphics are beautiful leaving me in awe on the first minutes of the game. While the game had some performance problems the first weeks they were later alleviated with patches making the performance on this game fantastic. The combat is fluid, the design of everything is breathtaking and the music is fantastic. There are a lot of weapons to use, diverse builds that you can create to change your playstyle, stat and resetting for trying something different. There is of course as every other Dark Souls game also multiplayer. You can read messages left by other players to aid you on your quest, you can coop with two or three other players and you can invade or be invaded by other players for player versus player.   As for the cons. The lack of covenant variety is sad and some covenants plain don't work correctly. There could had been some great stuff that could had been included on the covenants but given what is in the game the only ones who get constant activity are the pvp invasion covenants and the coop covenants. The covenants that rely on being summoned into a faction area almost never work and for some reason some players get summoned more than other players.  While PvP Arenas are finally in the game via it's first dlc I believe it's something that should had been on the base game. Regardless even with it's cons the game is still fantastic and I would greatly recommend it.

So here we are again for the third installment of Dark Souls. Those of you who are familiar with the series and have wandered through the ancient lands of Boletaria, Lordran, Drangleic, and maybe Yharnam, will feel right at home here in Lothric. I've loved every game of the 'Soulsborne' series so far (yes, even Dark Souls 2), and this one is no exception.  Much of the gameplay is the same but in this case that's not really a bad thing. You can still expect the same great challenges and adversity as in the previous games. Scores of weaponry, armor, and spells await your discovery, and hordes of horrors await you in their dread halls. To be honest, much of the equipment and spells you find are either completely useless or completely broken, but in my opinion learning which is which in PVE and PVP can be fun in and of itself.  And then, when you're done with the game and have absolutely destroyed every boss solo on NG+++++++ with your +10 blessed caestus (Punchie) and +10 hollow broadsword (Stabbie), the PVP arena awaits you where you can get absolutely destroyed over and over again by a horrifying, lanky, blueberry man while the onlooking crowd quietly mimes their cheers.  I'd definitely recommend adding this one to your library. Naturally you can wait for a big discount if you're the frugal sort. It doesn't really matter when as long as you get it in the end. And if you're new to the series, it's never too late to learn to git gud.  Praise the sun. 7/10.

Dark Souls 3 is, in a way, the ultimate way to tie up the series. From a story perspective, we as the Ashen One, are a mass of ashes from sacrificed individuals sent to decide the final fate of the world. Whether it is to plunge it into darkness, or keep it in the current age only a while longer. From a story perspective, it is a bit of a retreading through Dark Souls 1 mixed with new areas and bosses.    The only downsides are that From has screwed over Convenants with auto-summons. Being a mound maker is fun and hectic as you can attack anyone and everyone. However, being an Aldrich Faithful, a Blue Sentinel/Darkmoon, or a Farron Guard is annoying as you wait in invisible lines to maybe, probably be summoned to a gank fest. The game has lost a significant amount of the community as playing past level 100 sees very little amounts of players and making it very hard to 'farm' Covenant items. If you are planning on continuing to NG+ or NG++ and up, it's mostly going to be a solo battle.   As well, From deciced to port over the combat from Bloodborne as precise stabs are much less likely to help you win as spanking enemies with the fast sweeps of the straight sword stun locking any in its low stamina swings. This is only a minor gripe as it becomes kinda unfair when you just do 'R1 to win' with the straight swords.  I love Souls, all of them. All the flaws, all the weird enemy placements, all the dumb traps, all the pitfalls, everything. In a way, these show true determination. Once you start from nothing, stomp through hours upon hours of slicing and hacking your way through enemy mobs and invaders. Die from traps, swarming, or just getting bugged/stunlocked. You reach the final leg of your journey, the last boss, and you can look back at everything you've done and realize that 'through sheer determination, force of will, and self-induced hair loss, I did it. I made it here. And now, I'm gonna finish it, after I die about 3-4 times to figure out the boss' pattern!'

Some balancing issues (nothing crazy except for anything that's not a dex weapon being literally useless)  It's a good game, but living by From Software standards it's not great. There are gimmicky fights all over the game, but it's not overloaded with them really. It's sortof a middle grounds between dark souls 1 and 2, and what I mean by that is that it's not exactly as noob friendly as dark souls 2, but it leaves a lot to be desired when it comes to challenge and atmosphere. Granted I understand why you'd make a game more friendly to new players, but that sacrifices a lot of the charm of a souls game. Even as far as the dlc goes - spoliers: There is 1 main boss and 1 optional boss and neither are particularly challenging. You could easily clear the first dlc in a couple hours, and that's with finding every item. Then once you clear it, you notice that you got about 4 items actually worth something. Even back in Artorias of the Abyss, dlcs to the game added much more content including more explorable areas, more bosses, more items. It just leaves a lot to be desired.  Would I recommend it? Yes. Would I say that it's something that all souls fans will appreciate throughout? Definitely not. If they made improvements could the game be amazing? Yes, and I will continue to believe that even if the developers speak to me directly and tell me why they aren't making those changes.  Overall verdict: 6/10. Worth playing, but not as much as other titles from this developer.

If you have played the first Dark Souls, and even Demon's Souls, this game is a real treat, so many callbacks i.e. a bit fan-servicery, but that's a good thing. Dark Souls III is more of a sequel to the first game than the second one was. The same framework in terms of the mechanics and lore/world-building is there, combat definitely a bit smoother, still as nuanced and many styles to go with; strength, dexterity, magic-focused, etc.   The world-building and level design, though some parts derivative of their previous games, it is sublime. And the boss battles, so rememberable, and with a great soundtrack to compliment each, and the whole game in general. Dark Souls doesn't hold your hold and over-feed you with direction and lore like most games, it has this wonderful mystery about it and when you go searching for that lore and going in whatever direction you take, it can be wonderful. Even more fun putting your own interpretion on it as some of it can come off as ambigious, which I think is intended by the developer, as was the case in their previous Souls games and Bloodborne.  Game even has multiplayer, PVP and PVE, you can summon a co-op buddy to help you with boss battles or against dark spirits i.e. people who invade other people's worlds, which I dabbled in and was extremely fun, and I'm not really a multiplayer guy! There's a sense of sportsmanship with this, you bow to one another and then commence fighting, no health potion taking (well, sometimes, not everyone is the same unnfortunately) and make more funny gestures via the silly and wonderful gesture system, Praise the Sun anymore!  Dark Souls III is one of the most immersive, eerie, dark, and wonderful RPGs I have played in years and since the first Dark Souls game, and can't wait to see what more From Software can offer but as for this series, this is a fantastic end to an already fantastic trilogy. What to say about Dark Souls 3, is it a good game?   Pros: 1) The level design is good 2) The game itself is so good to look at 3) Offers a lot to do regardless of it being smaller than the other two games 4) Co-op connecting is simpler 5) The different quests and how to get them are interesting 6) Runs smooth even the controls whether it be controller or keyboard and mouse 7) It gives a feel of nostalgia, offering similarities between Dark Souls 1 and itself 8) Multiplayer (invasions, etc.) is better than before in my opionion 9) Get all the weapons that the enemies have and not far as I can see  Cons: 1) Boss/enemy difficulty could be more resistant, just a bit more at least between playthroughs as they felt the same 2) Kind of annoying to see every phantom sign near enough to say the words 'Unable to summon Phantom' 3) It would be nice to have something like the bonfire ascetic back or something similar but thats my opinion  I don't really have a problem with this game at all and don't let me by saying the boss and enemy difficulty could be more resistant put you off as the game is still quite a challenge, I said that mainly for additional playthroughs. To be honest as I'm having fun with the game I do recommend it especially if you have played the others and I cannot wait to see what they do to expand the game with DLC.  Bugs: Now whilst a lot of people have been having issues with the game I've only incountered two bugs.  1)The First is when creating a character and choosing any hair or facial hair and going through the options too fast can cause the right side screen which shows what your character looks like freezes. Now the three ways I found to unfreeze and get around it were, start character creation again. Two is save the character and then load it and go through it again so you don't have the to hassle at the start of it again. Three, go really slow when choosing the hair orfacial hair.  2)The second bug was when playing the game after a long duration realy players in invasions or co-op would start sliding instead of showing themselves walking and in rare cases the boses would also slide doing no damage to players that have joined a host to fight said boss.

I've seen Dark Souls 1, but this is the first Souls game I've actually played. And it certainly hasn't disappointed.  Yes, the game is hard, but it's also completely fair. There's a gimmick to every enemy and boss, and the trick is to use them to your advantage, while throwing in some of your own skill. This is nicely supplemented by the new mechanics, like weapon skills, which add a new sort of flavor to the combat.  I've beaten three bosses so far, and it's funny that the first one gave me the most trouble -- at least one of the other two I killed in one try while taking no damage. And yet, it doesn't really feel that you've become more powerful, but instead that you as a player have grown in experience, which is an intensely satisfying feeling and what makes the Souls games so appealing.  Oh, and the game looks gorgeous, the voice acting is superb, the soundtrack is excellent, and I've experienced very minimal technical difficulty. So there's that.  In short, don't think you have to be a hardcore gamer to enjoy this game. Anyone can conquer Dark Souls with enough perseverence and determination, and once you do it's a sense of victory unlike any other.

So at first I felt bored because the game was just too easy, even when I was barely leveling up status. Then I fought one of the best bosses ever (coffcoffAbyss Watcherscoffcoff), and now I think this might be my favorite game of the series so far.  The OST and audio effects are great, the gameplay is better and faster, and the visuals are better than DS2 but they still look downgraded even at max settings, yet again.  There are new and cooler weapons, and the TP bar that is used for magic/miracles as well as new special techniques each weapon type has. So now instead of having magic/miracles that can only be used exactly 3 times can now be used as long as you have enough TP.  Lorewise, we are back to the same place where DS1 happened, so...you might see some familiar faces around? But the new characters are also great. They have backstory that you need to discover yourself, and I somehow got attached to some of them without realizing and even got ♥♥♥♥ing worried sick when they disappeared on me...  Now for the bad part. Honestly, the only bad thing I can think about this game is that the online gameplay sometimes is laggy. Not that this is new to any DarkSouls player, but this time you will see the other players standing literally static, just the model frozen and hovering around you. For coop this isnt that bad, but if its PVP you will not see the other player moves, so you wont know what the ♥♥♥♥ he is attacking you with so good luck trying to defend yourself. Theres also a annoying hiccup that randomly happen while opening/closing menus, when the game is saving, or when you are just walking around. Its not that bad but when it happens at crucial moments it annoys the ♥♥♥♥ outta me. Oh, and if you care about character customization, have fun with this one. For some weird reason From Software decided to make the character model face all glued togheter, so if you try to change the chin you will be also changing the mouth, or if you change the brows the eyes are going to move too, or change the lips color and watch the whole ♥♥♥♥ing face of you character turn green. YES, GREEN! What the actual ♥♥♥♥, From?!  Though they did add more customization options and its possible to make a decent character, but be prepared to waste more time on it than should have been necessary...   Overall, this game is really worth the money, and its safe to say you will put a good chunk of your free time in it. I havent even finished the game yet and I'm already hyped to start another playthrough! If you are scared about people's complaining about the game not running at all for them, wait till they are done patching the game. But I honestly recommend getting it now while the new players still need to git gud and their souls are fresh and delicious. Praise the ♥♥♥♥ing Old Wolf!

in dark souls 2 you just popped into a completely different area, in dark souls 3 you find something from a previous souls game despite the area having no relation to whatever it is you just found.  in addition, some weapons have pretty much no reason to be in the game, the pursuers greatshield is just sitting in the cathedral of the deep, ricards rapier is dropped from some naked dude summoned in archdragon peak. if that naked dude is ricard himself, it makes even less sense. i would prefer if the game atleast better explained why theyre just, well, there.  the bosses are the high point of dark souls 3. theyre all very memorable in their own unique way, with balanced difficulty, and creative design. npcs and their quest lines are also interesting and unique. each npc has their own story, and either fit into the main story very well, or are mostly seperate. my only complaint is that you usually have to actually go out of your way to complete an npcs questline. i never completed a single npc questline in my first playthrough, because the npc was in an area i didnt particularly enjoy to go through, requiring really specific criteria to continue the questline or in the last place yould expect them to be.  all in all, dark souls 3 is a wasted opportunity, miyazaki is clearly capable of making a really, really good game (bloodborne, dark souls 1), but he dropped the ball with stale, boring pvp, garbage invasions horribly stacked in the hosts favor, hardly any new mechanics besides weapon arts, and just reusing many aspects from past souls games. the multiplayer is supposed to keep you playing the game, but that isnt the case because the pvp is boring and consist of the same 4 or 5 meta weapons that are good because everything else is trash.  i really wanted to like the pvp, and i still want to. the dlc is the only hope i have for this game, but i doubt theyll make the pvp not complete garbage and boring.

This is probably the best action game i've ever played, by far.  First, I want to point out that I got this game on PC through steam, and quickly realized it wasn't intended to be played with a keyboard and mouse. I also crashed multiple times on the lowest settings and also had severe framerate drops (on a pretty decent computer). I ended up getting a steam refund (thank god that was an option) and getting the game for Xbox One and have since put in about 60 hours. If you don't have a steam controller and a strong PC, I strongly advise you to look into a different platform.  It's true that this game is difficult. To my surprise though, it's not that frustrating for me. I go into the game knowing that some enemies are going to mop the floor with me, sometimes repeatedly. This was especially true on my first playthrough. Here are some tips to keep the frustration to a minimum.  one: Keep the stakes low. When you die, you drop all of your souls (currency). you have a chance to pick them up near the place you died, but if you die again before you pick them up, they're gone. For this reason, when you reach a bonfire (checkpoint), make it a habit to go back to the Firelink Shrine (your home base) and spend your souls.  two: Don't force yourself to play when you're not in the mood. This game, by nature is very stressful, even when you're doing well. If you're not eager to play, and you have a sense of dread about a new area, take a break, and don't play until you really want to.  three: Don't set high expectations. Nomatter what skill level you are in other games, you will always start as a noob in Dark Souls. Knowing each enemy is crucial. You will die a lot on your first playthrough. Just keep in mind that with every failed attempt, you get a little better. (by the way, there's no easy-mode difficulty setting)  four: The key to being good at this game is patience. It's the times you try to breeze through an area that you get your organs served to you on a plate. With the way the combat system works, fighting multiple enemies is a terrible idea. Use a range weapon to lure them one at a time. There are also a lot of ambushes. Excersize caution around ledges, doorways and dark areas where enemies might hide. Also keep in mind that some items are meant to lure you. If you don't mind spoilers, use online resources. Watch playthroughs and guides, and read up on the Dark Souls wiki.  The combat in this game is extremely engaging and doesn't get old. Since every enemy has the potential to ruin your day, it really keeps you on your toes. The combat is all about timing, and since each enemy has different behavior, attacks and weaknesses, it's crucial to know each enemy. If your smart, you'll find yourself occasionally taking the time to study how an enemy fights, rather than killing them the first chance you get. If you love games with intense combat systems, you'll love Dark Souls.  Another thing this game does great is that it has excelent replayability. There are about ten different character classes that you get to start with. There are also different styles of combat and classes of weapons. You can be a greatsword/shield wielding knight, a dual wielding mercenary, a katana wielding assassin, a sourcerer, a stealth archer, etc. The list goes on and on. On top of that, when you finish a the game, you have the option to start again from the beginning, keeping your levels and equipment, but having an increased difficulty. The only thing I feel is missing from this game is the ability to fight bosses multiple times.  There is also multiplayer, which is very well incorporated into the game. I currently don't have Xbox Live Gold, so I can't talk much about it, but people seem to enjoy it.  The Dark Souls series has a very complex and interesting underlying lore that it leaves you to figure out on your own. You can learn about the lore through item descriptions, talking to NPCs, ect. You can also learn alot about the lore through online resources. There are entire forums dedicated to speculating and discussing the lore. If you don't want to delve into the lore, you don't have to, but it's a great addition to the game if you find it interesting.  Bottom line, this game is amazing. This is one of the few games I can play for hours without realizing it. I highly reccomend it to someone looking for a challenge.

-Logs in to Dark Souls 3- -Sees '[CAUTION] INVALID GAME DATA HAS BEEN DETECTED' -Plugs in a controller -Gets softbanned  Moral of the story is, don't cheat folks, because controllers lead to very bad penalties 10/10 would Cheat Engine again.   *NOW FOR THE SERIOUS REVIEW*  Dark Souls 3 is by far one of the most anticipated games for me, and when the game finally came out I was very surprised with the results it gave me.  You start out in these ruin like places and learn the controls, next thing that spotted my eye was the Ashen Estus this is basically an estus for the new(ish) mechanic Focus Points (mana bar) and basically is only prioritized when playing a magic user.  Next thing that caught my attention was Firelink Shrine, this was the old area in the original Dark Souls and it was a pretty great HUB world in both games. You have the firekeeper who you can talk to level up, the blacksmith (ANDRE THE ONE AND ONLY) and he upgrades your weapons or infuses them. The only thing they didn't bring back, was upgrading armor like in the first souls game. I like that idea, it makes armor more unique rather than just something you would wear to look cool while being OP. With using 'estus shards' you can upgrade your estus at Andre; as well as alloting estus, which is a way to divide your estus' up.  You can find various NPC's to add to Firelink Shrine, most of the time they sell some pretty nice goods that will aid you on your quest.  Up next is the Shrine Handmaid, she's your ordinary merchant who sells you goods, but the catch is, you can find ashes and give them to her so she can put new things in her shop. Other than that, kind of a boring merchant.  Let's talk about the 'ember' system, it acts just as the human effigy from Dark Souls 2 and doesn't really have much of a difference, you use it to gain access to summoning phantoms to help you on your journey. It also gives you more health.  Online play is the same as every other souls game, you use a soapstone to be summoned to kill the next boss, and the PVP is probably what really stood out in this game. It's the same as the others but it combines many mechanics and gimics from the previous games that make it really enjoyable.     If you haven't already bought this game, I highly recommend it to people who want to get into this franchise. It's a wonderful experience and will always keep you busy with something      8/10

Pros: -Much more detailed back story. In other souls games the back story was very VERY fragmented into item descriptions and in game objects. In DS3 NPC's give you clues about the back story and what you need to do. -Very optimized for AMD. I ran this 60fps 1080p max settings on an AMD HD 7970.. which is a very old card. -Combat is very fluid and unique. -Bosses and NPC's are really challenging. Maybe too challenging. Some bosses are almost impossible to beat solo because their attack patterns are just very random. -The map is very big and detailed.  -It mixes up biblical and roman mythology along with the back story. Some enemies look like Church Members of the Inquisition. -Did I say the game was extremelly challenging? -Enemy NPC's are more aggressive than in other Souls Games. This is good because it requires for the player to pay much more attention or he'll/she'll die constantly.    Cons: -Bloodborne Engine makes metal pieces look plastic.  -Casters are at a disadvantage with the whole FP mechanic. -Irithyll feels WAY too much like bloodborne. I'm betting Fromsoftware reused many 3d objects and textures. Even some of the Enemy NPC's look like bloodborne NPC's. -Some of the armors and weapons are from Bloodborne. I understand re-using things from older DS games, but Bloodborne is just an entirely different universe. -Like all other Souls like games, it would be much better if it had a bigger safe areas with, maybe, quests to do.

If you enjoyed the previous souls game or Bloodborne you'll love it. Arguably the best in the series. Souls games typically get extremely good DLC for around $15 quarterly, so expect to want to pick that up when you buy this. Dont buy this game if your a casual player that likes to just play a few rounds of bejewelled and get easy wins. This game is designed to be hard and its quests are obscure. PvP is mandatory if your playing online and if your being invaded then that players only goal is to ruin your day. There are no fair pvp fights outside of arena battles with players looking for the same thing.  Now to get to why you should buy this game. Its awesome. The combat system is great and while offensive magic needs work currently weapons are fun to use and easy to learn. Your not learning how to master a long string of combos when you use a weapon, you have a basic series of attacks and from there you make your own style of combat. You can use daggers and aim to crit people or you can use a longsword and keep your distance while dealing heavy strikes. Its up to you how you play.  The story requires your attention. Your not given alot of it on a platter so you have to look for it. Read item discriptions and find npcs that arent on the beaten path. There are multiple endings and each one takes effort to achieve. When you accomplish anything it actually feels like you achieved something and didnt just grind enough to hit some threshold. You can complete this game as a lvl 1 character if your feeling optimistic.

After playing this game to completion I have to say (and I know many will disagree) this is my favorite souls game to date. I feel like it is probably a little easier than some of them, which is a great way to bring on new players, but it 100% isn't an 'easy' game. There were many areas which had me pulling my hair out (I'm looking at you Poison swamp), but for the most part every aspect of this game is well designed. In fact I liked everything so much I started out as a pure pyro build at the beginning, but then respeced to sorcery, then respeced again to focus on dex....and I really am thinking about instead of doing NG+ to go back and run a miracle focused character. Everything I tried I loved, so picking on one playstyle and sticking with it was tough.   Like most souls games the story isn't laid out for you, but rather makes you want to dig deeper into the text, and research the community online to figure out what is going on which is great. It will be especially confusing if you have not played any other souls games in the series, but you should still get the general idea of it, and may even make you want to go back and play DS 1 and 2.   There are a lot of people worried about bugs and game crashes, but I have a solid gaming PC and never had a single issue, even with everything running on max settings.   All in all I would 100% recommend this to others. 9.5/10

Solid gameplay as per usual. Rolling mechanics and movement are the best they have been in the entire series. Plot is more of the same. Chosen undead, err... unkindled I mean, fire dying pls go link. But you can choose to tell the world to ♥♥♥♥ off in various ways if you please.  PvP as of this writing is in a sad state, entire covenants are reported as broken by many players. Certain weapon classes are very very overpowered and the new quick healing and summon mechanics allow for elongated battles with many gank squads.  Poise, a mainstay of the series has been removed, albeit very haphazardly. There have been findings that by changing the value of a byte in the game's code that it can be turned back on, pointing to the idea that this removal was done hastily and at the last minute. However still, as of a month to the day after release in the West we have not received any real response from the developer as to why it was disabled. What makes this especially puzzling is poise is still included in the game as a value on all armor and boosted specifically by a few rings. This limits the style of gameplay available to melee builds. A tank spec trading hit for hit with enemies is no longer viable, and groups of rats can stunlock even a heavily armored high level player to death in seconds with no recourse. This forces a more Bloodborne-esque style of gameplay which is accented by the ease of dodging and rolling added to this game.  Boss fights are much faster paced than the previous games and if you can get used to the dodging playstyle they can be more visceral and fun. The boss fights feel less like a game of chess and more like a twitch shooter with their added speed.  The level design takes a step up from Dark Souls 2, however it does not reach the elegance obtained by areas such as the Undead Burg, Blighttown, Valley of Drakes connections, or Painted World in Dark Souls 1. It seems to be a mixture of the two. Separated areas split apart in the game world, like DaS 2, however once in those isolated zones the level design takes a nice wrap around approach like DaS 1, with mainstays like opening shortcuts and the reuse of bonfires.  NG+ and ++, which are the two I experienced going for all achievements are a let down compared to previous games. There are no new enemies, boss mechanics, or items outside of +1,2 and 1 +3 rings. The difficulty does not rise accordingly and such can be a slog to get through if you are not the type of person able to play through the same game multiple times in a row, such as myself.  Side quests for NPC's can be very opaque. To the level that I do not expect people to be able to complete them without the use of a guide, which is never acceptable in my opinion. If you are going for 100% completion a guide will be needed and will be best used after your first playthrough so you can have that first blind wondrous playthrough. Do not worry however as everything else can be obtained through the course of NG+ and ++, which you will need to go through anyway in order to get all the endings and rings needed for 100% completion.    Overall a very solid game, and above average when compared to the modern day action RPG. However coming from the A team at FROM (Miyazaki) and the lack of communication on issues such as poise and covenants being obviously broken, stops this from reaching the heights of Dark Souls 1. Let's see what's in store for us from the DLC.
