I'm honestly not sure what to think about this entry into the Souls series, it does many things right, and many things wrong. However, I've nonetheless had tons of fun with this game, and I'll give it a recommendation. The following are my opinions upon the game, which are purely stemmed from my experiences with it.  OVERVIEW: Dark souls 3 is the third entry into the Dark Souls series, and the fifth entry into the Souls-like style of games From Software has become known for making (excluding SoFS). This time, the world is on the brink of a bitter conclusion, the fire fades, with no Lords of Cinder to rekindle the flame. You, the Unkindled, attempted to link the First Flame in the past, but failed to due so. With the world in dire straights, you are brought back from the dead to find the missing Lords of Cinder, and return them to their thrones. Combat is quick and unforgiving, and you'll find yourself dying many times on your path to success. Like any Souls-like, patience and practice are well-needed to survive the dark. Additionally, Hidetaki Miyazaki was brought back as the director of the game, and it's easy to spot his influence on the game if you've played previous entries in the series. We'll get to this in the next section.  THE GOOD: -Many of the disliked aspects of Dark Souls 2 have been given the boot. Firstly, animations are fare less floaty, and feel crisp and smooth. Level design is far less linear, and packed with various branching pathways and secrets to explore. Second, the dreaded plight of Soul Memory is gone, instead replaced with the favored Soul Level matchmaking system. Weapon upgrade level is included in matching players, meaning equal power levels between combatants or cooperators in multiplayer. Finally, enemies no longer despawn after being killed a few times. -Melee combat is well-paced, and makes for an exhilarating experience. Being rewarded for patient and smart play is one of the most outstanding aspects of the Souls series, and Dark Souls 3 is no exception. Aggressive enemies teach new players to hold back their lust to charge blindly, and even provide a challenge for veterans to the series. Placement of these foes is fair most of the time, and enemies no longer aggro in groups (like in Dark Souls 2). -Bosses are fantastic in Dark Souls 3, with each having two phases to the fight, and beautiful accompanying themes. None of these bosses are re-used, and only two show up later game as enemies.  -Lastly, the lore and references make for a fantastic backstory for the world's path to destruction. Many impressively deep theories have been written upon various boss and NPC relations to and influence upon the world.  THE BAD: -Poise. While I hate to keep beating an already dead topic, poise is a huge issue in this game. The lack of 'classic' poise, or the ability to withstand certain attacks without being stunned, is essential to a faster-paced Souls game. I found myself dying to otherwise avoidable attacks and being constantly stunlocked by other players because of this. While the changes to poise certainly allow interesting combos to be achieved in multiplayer, many weapons are tossed aside in favor of quick, stunlocking weapons. For example, using a rapier or straightsword and spamming attacks for all eternity is extremely viable, and stupidly annoying to counter without being stuck into a stunlock due to a failed parry. -Invasions are horribly imbalanced, with too much being given in favor of the host. Constant phantoms can be summoned with no penalty on the host, leading to nearly endless struggles between an invader and a stream of summons. Invaders receive a health reduction and halved estus, reducing chances of success even further. Even more aggravating is the existence of the Seed of a Tree of Giants, an item that turns enemies upon the invader. This literally forces invaders to rely upon things such as one-shot or high-damage builds to gain a smidgen of a chance at success. I keep to 1v1 duels for my PvP, as do a majority of players nowadays. While invasions can certainly hamper progression, they bring a unique aspect to the franchise. To see them so neglected is a shame. -While map design is spot on, the individual locations are placed in a linear manner, unlike the branching world of Dark Souls. It's not a huge issue, but it's sad to see the linear world design return from Dark Souls 2. -Covenants are disappointing, Watchdogs of Farron and Aldritch Faithful only differ in location, and Blue Sentinels and Blades of the Darkmoon are a joke. It doesn't help that most of these were bugged upon release, and simply did not function until a patch that came nearly a month later. -Hackers are a literal blight upon this game, and are killing the multiplayer. However, it's on the fault of the developers for implementing a useless anti-cheat system. Modifications to one's stats are rarely detected, but modifying a non-hacking player's stats via cheating in multiplayer lead to the innocent player being banned. From Software's has barely done anything to solve this issue, and a vast majority of players have simply quit the game because of this ridiculousness. -That one area with the bajillion jailers in Irithyll Dungeons, please. These are my personal opinions, take care to view them as such  CONCLUSION: As mentioned before, Dark Souls 3 does a lot of things right, and a lot of things wrong. I jokingly compare this series to the Super Smash Bros franchise as a reference to how the entries feel. Overall, I feel as though Dark Souls 3 attempted to combine aspects from Dark Souls and Dark Souls 2, with a mixed bag of results. -Demon's Souls is Super Smash Bros 64. An experiment to test the waters for a new take at an otherwise old concept. Not expected to reach success, the game managed to surprise many with fun-factor. -Dark Souls is Super Smash Bros Melee. The most beloved of the franchise, it brought much attention to the fledgling Souls name. Gameplay was hardcore, but harsh to new players. -Dark Souls 2 is Super Smash Bros Brawl. Still a great game, but lacked the depth and magic the previous entries flaunted. Best played with other people for the refined PvP. (difference here is Brawl's mechanics for battles being so godawful) -Bloodborne is Project M. A new take on a beloved game, but nonetheless different from that it attempts to mimic. Well-received and loved by fans for its interesting style. -Dark Souls 3 is Super Smash Bros for Wii U. Some hate it, but others love it, it's particularly despised by despised by older fans. It's an easy game to get into, catering more towards beginners than franchise veterans.

Dark Souls 3 is the latest in a venerable series of games, starting with Demon's Souls. Dark Souls has always been about risk versus reward, with challenges balanced around progress, better equipment, and growth as a character and player. Enemy placemnent has always allowed carefully progressing players to know what's coming up ahead and plan, and in theory, even at level 1, a player could overcome these obstacles with judicious planning.   How does Dark Souls 3 stand up to these traditions? Rather well, I'd say! You start out with next to nothing (unless you pick the Deprived class. Then it IS nothing!) and must crawl, scrape, and fight your way past giants, demons, and the legions of mad undead to save a dying world.   Layout in the game is fairly gentle for the first few areas, with either a few aggressive enemies or a clump of passive nonhostile undead. This changes quickly, and you learn cautious use of a bow is a requirement to peel off dangerous foes, and that any group more then two or three is a death sentence, especially early on.   Late game challenge is found not in large mobs or waves of foes, but rather strong, agile enemies that work together. One of the hardest fights is three NPCs who fight together, flanking you, distracting you, and healing while you're dodging their allys' attacks.  Overall, I'm eagerly awaiting the launch of the DLCs, and I recommend this to anyone who wants a good game to try. Just prepare to die at first.

This is a fantastic game. Classic Dark Souls formula: if you enjoyed 1 & 2 you will enjoy this one. I've logged around 140 hours at the time of writing and I feel that this is well worth the full price I paid for it plus the season pass.  Pros:  - Beautiful environments - Fast, fluid combat - Easily accessible and good co-op (you can co-op regardless of weapon/level difference) - Excellent PVE - Interesting & memorable bosses - Huge areas (though not interconnected like DS1) - New weapons & weapon skills, never before seen in Dark Souls - Possibly the best PVP combat of any Souls game - Easily the best overall multiplayer of any Souls game  Cons:  - All bosses use the 'half health final form' thing (minor complaint, its just overused) - Covenants really suck compared to previous iterations. - No blue eye orb: ranking Darkmoon can be difficult. - DS2's NG+ system does not return. Health/damage bonuses only. - Invading slightly unfair to invaders (estus/health difference) - PVP build variety is seriously lacking.  * PVP variety:   - Magic straight up blows in PVP. There's no way around it. It's just bad. - Quality builds are unquestionably superior to all other builds. If you're good at PVP you can make pretty much anything that's not magic work, but quality builds are king and everything else is just objectively worse. This hurts variety and can be very boring at times. If you like quality builds however I suppose this will be a good thing. - Element enchants are... not as good as they were in the other Souls games. Lightning enchants, for instance, always lose vs a str/dex enchanted weapon with a lightning buff, even when the weapon has an S or A FTH scaling. They're fine for PVE but for PVP you're just gimping yourself. - Shields are meh. Greatshields are viable but they take considerable stat investment when it's usually better to just roll. Very small shields are excellent for parrying but there are weapons that can do the job just as well (with the bonus of being able to have a fast off-hand weapon.) Medium shields are almost entirely useless in PVP, though excellent for PVE. - Certain spells/buffs/rings/effects are nerfed to the point of ineffectuality in PVP. Since you can get by without them in PVE this makes a good chunk of items/spells effectively useless.  THAT SAID: the PVP is still very, very good. It is amazingly easy to find duels and fight clubs, but I'd be lying if I said there were no problems with it.  Overall I have to say that this game is a worthy final chapter in the Dark Souls trilogy, and that's before the 2 planned DLC have dropped. Ashes of Andariel drops October 25th and I can't wait!

I thought a long time about how to rate this game.  'Should i rate it as it's own game or in comparison to it's predecessors?'  I decided to rate it in comparison: It still get's a thumbs up, but it's close not to, it may be a good SoulsBorne game but as a Dark Souls game i feel it is lacking something and has a few things it shouldn't. In my opinion Dark Souls 3 has only a few new things to offer but some of them are either not really original or overshadowed by things from previous games (looking at you armour sets). The weapon arts are a nice addition but are just not useful on some weapons (like on a certain great hammer), the faster combat works well with PvP...  theoretically. The faster fighting gives a great opportunity for interesting and adrenaline-soaking fights but sadly makes a lot of slower weapons unviable.  PvE wise the game is really great, a lot of interesting bosses, weapons and lore. Since (like in every Souls game) any weapon/build can carry you through the game there is a huge diversity between each playthrough if you want to since every fight will always play out differently (except the fact that you either win or die).  I do hope they bring back some of the Dark Souls 2 spells back though.  On my first playthrough the creativity felt a bit forced but after i realized how short this game was i was glad they put so much thought into it, which brings up another point where the game falls short: it's shortness. Dark Souls 3 is by far the shortest of the last 3 SoulsBorne games (never played Demons so i can't compare it to that) and that wouldn't be so bad if the level-design was as complex as in DS1. The enemy design is mostly put together very well except for the fact that some enemys behave as if they were in Bloodborne (fast and almost indodgeable).  All in all it's a solid title with some things they could have done better, it feels more like a well made, fanmade Dark Souls mod for Bloodborne.

Though customisation and replayability is severely lacking compared to the previous Dark Souls games, it is definitively the best From Software game yet.  Everything deserves praise.  But personally I think there are some very blunt downsides.  Firstly, I was greatly disappointed by the amount of re-used content from previous games. Almost half of locations, enemies, weapons, armor and spells was just copied from previous games. With minor barely noticable changes.  Secondly, the game felt like it had little to no difficulty whatsoever in terms of discovery. As if the developers intentionally added methods to make the game all too easy to navigate and cut a lot of corners to reduce both backtracking and freedom of exploration. There's very little challenge in getting around and shortcuts are abundant.  Thirdly, and largely personal preference; The game is simply not hard enough. Online Phantoms make too much of a difference, even ending up solo-ing most bosses whilst the world Host stays in a safe corner and watches. And there are quite a few 'crutch'-concepts, items and methods to exploit the workings of the game. Compared to the other Dark Souls, it does not feel like there is any freedom to strategise, just one way, one path. Though multiple drop-down points and shortcuts are available, they all ultimately lead to the same result.  Barring these three flaws, it is simply one of the greatest games of all time and it should stay that way.

Thank you FromSoftware; as a bored adult gamer, you’ve brought the real joys of gaming to me once again.  TL;DR: Been getting bored of games fairly quickly in the last few years and didn’t seem to have much attention span for most. Then bought Dark Souls 3 when it came out as my first ever Souls game in the series, got massively hooked and felt the real joys of gaming again. Bought the other 2 as well as a PS4 so I could play Bloodborne and now I’m a complete addict!  I have been a gamer since I remember, and now in my early 30’s, for the past few years, I found myself getting bored of games very quickly. From AAA’s to indie games I’d mostly end up playing them just so I can beat them and be done with them so I could move on to the next title, like ticking chores off a list, and quite often not even bother finishing the game at all (I’m sorry The Divinity, you were one of the better games I played recently!) I’d known about the Soul games for years, but had been hesitant to even try them for fear of frustration and boredom from their infamous difficult gameplay and the countless deaths phenomena. Until a few months ago I saw an interesting video that delved deep into the Soul games’ sense of exploration, and the rewarding factor of the games - something I truly realised later on when I played the games - so i decided to pick up Dark Souls 3 upon its release a couple of months ago. After countless hours of frustration and deaths (as expected), I realised I must be doing something wrong; I may not be a real hardcore gamer, but surely I can’t be that bad? That’s when I decided to read up on the games mechanics, stats system, guides on how to play as a noob, what starter class to pick, guides on parrying and so on and on and on. So I started a new game, picked up a knight and started to play properly. Never have I ever found myself so immersed in a game in such a long long time. I invested so much time in the game, not only by playing, but also reading up about every bit of the game - something that I’d barely and rarely done with any game before, unless it was a little walkthrough through some section of some game I was stuck at or some such. I studied the maps and made sure I missed not a single item. I read up on all different NPC’s and quest lines to make sure I’d make the most of the play-through, something I realised later wasn’t possible to achieve in just one play-through. So not so shockingly, I started the NG+ once I beat the game so I can achieve 100% achievement completion: an idea that I would’ve laughed off at in any previous games that I’d played. “Who gives a damn about achievements?' Nonetheless, I loved this game so much I bought the kickstarter board game and the other 2 Soul games in the series, which I’m yet to play because I ended up buying a PS4 (that came with Uncharted4) just so I can play Bloodborne. Yes, I’m really that much affected (read: obsessed) by these games. And Bloodborne: what an utterly gorgeous game. It’d probably come as to no surprise at this rate to say that I even ordered the game’s guidebook, to save myself from countless amounts of internet checking (which I still do anyway!). I could write a long post about how amazing this game is but I’ll save that for another time! So thank you again FromSoftware for making some of the most amazing games in all my years of gaming experience, and bringing back the joys of gaming again to this bored-no-more adult gamer. My wallet may hate your guts, but I love you.

With nearly 200 hours into the game, I think it's safe to say that I have a general feel on what I think of the game. Since I have 200 hours in, you'd think that I enjoy this installment quite a bit, and I can say that I did, AT FIRST.  This of course changed after completing my first playthrough, roughly 60 hours into the game. The game, unlike pretty much every installment in the franchise, gets stale after the first playthrough -- not only is there a lack of incentive to enter NG+, but the actual new games and onward are very dissapointing, adding nothing but new upgraded rings. It's a far cry from the brilliant new game experience of the second game, which not only added these upgraded rings, but also changed enemy placement and added new enemies in general (making NG+ feel like an actual new game).  This leads to my next point; Dark Souls III takes heavy inspiration from the first game in the franchise (along with Bloodborne, which I have yet to play). With inspiration can come dependence, and thus, fan service aplenty. This fan service was present in pretty much every aspect of the game, including the story, equipment, environments, etc... It almost made me mad in some parts when I saw blatant references and the like when I was playing through, and in hindsight, nearly half of the game was content that had already been used or covered before in past installments (Dark Souls I in particular -- there was nearly no Dark Souls II fanservice or acknowledgement whatsoever).  Now for my major criticism -- weapon variety. At first glance, one might think that there are a great amount of unique weapons in this game, based off of all of the different weapon types and different backgrounds to certain weapons within these categories. Bully for me (and many others as well), when I learned that there were next to no differences between most of these weapons. Each spear was the same, each dagger was the same, each thrusting sword was the same... You get the idea. The only weapons that had unique properties to them were boss weapons, or weapons wielded by NPCs in the game (and most of these weapons weren't even that good, since they can't be infused or buffed, and generally have unsatisfactory AR). They may have had unique movesets, being the only real catch to using these weapons, but it isn't really worth that much, considering the player can just equip a short sword or thrusting sword and easy mode the game (PvP included). There are really only two viable weapon classes in this game, regardless of all the patching that was made to 'nerf' these weapons.  This lack of weapon variety translates into stale PvP, which is what gives these games longevity (at least, in the past). Couple that with a poor matchmaking system, terrible network connectivity, unbalanced rolling, lack of working mechanics (which work as intended, if you know what I mean), and abundance of overpowered mechanics (bleed says hello, and poison says goodbye).  Here are my overall, brief reflections on the game, so you can see how I would rank this game:  PROS:  - Fast-paced combat - Mostly excellent bosses - Beautiful character and environmental art - Slightly primitive but nice graphic fidelity - Really nicely implemented difficulty curve (the best in the franchise) - Nice progression (story and gameplay wise) and pacing - Fashion Souls is as good as ever (although not as great as Dark Souls II's fashion) - Great level design by area in most cases - Very atmospheric and mood-setting - Cool lore (in most cases)  CONS: - Very limited weapon variety (lack of viable weapons) - Abundant fan service - Poor matchmaking and connectivity - Lack of replay value - Unbalanced game mechanics in some cases - Lack of game mechanics in some cases - Linear, boring world design  - Certain useless Weapon Arts  Overall, I recommend this game to anyone who has played any of the past games -- I'm sure that you would still like it. Don't get me wrong, I still enjoy the game, but I do honestly think that it's the worst in the franchise.  6/10.

Absolutely brilliant game and a beautiful sendoff to one of my favorite series. Some key missteps aside, Dark Souls III is arguably the pinnacle of the series and builds up on everything FROM Software has learned in the ~5 years since Dark Souls 1 came out (~7 if we include Demon's Souls).  In short for those of you unfamiliar with the series, Dark Souls III is a highly atmospheric action-RPG with a heavy emphasis on weighty melee combat (or flashy spells, if you go that route). While it's set in a fantasy world, the world is decayed and bleak to the point where you wouldn't be mistaken for confusing it for an action-horror title. Like the previous games in the series, Dark Souls III is notorious for being brutal, (but personally, it's not that hard once you come to grips with the mechanics and understand how the game wants you to play).   Dark Souls III, like the previous titles, has extremely little exposition and cutscenes are sparse, so you need to actively read item descriptions and talk to the few NPCs that pop up in your journey (as well as fill in the missing pieces) to get a more complete story. That being said, what lore and dialogue that you find are incredibly intriguing and have led to some really creative fan theories (shout-out to /r/DarkSouls3)  As for the major differences in Dark Souls III compared to the previous games, while there are many tweaks to the core gameplay, it feels right at home, focusing more on refining the formula rather than overhauling it (like in Dark Souls II). Combat in PvE is arguably the best in the series. Each melee weapon now has more depth (since you can now charge heavy melee attacks and perform various weapon arts) and the enemy design in this game is really impressive (while you have your typical 'doods in armor', you also have some really creepy and disgusting looking enemies - very similar in a sense to the monsters in Bloodborne).  The game's also a lot faster paced, since the player's roll got significantly sped up in this game (and has a lot of invulnerability frames, letting you be really aggressive). On the flip side of the coin, enemies are also really aggressive as well, so you can't be reckless.  If you like boss fights, then Dark Souls III delivers in spades. Dark Souls III really focuses on having aggressive boss fights, usually in the form of duels (though there are some extremely large boss fights, though these tend to be gimmicky and not all that enjoyable) and they're an absolute blast. I'd say that there are few bad boss fights in this game, with over half of the bosses in the game are absolutely delightful, with most of the rest being okay, with only about 5 (out of the 19 bosses) that were particularly bad.  As for the bad of the game:  Poise (your resistance to stuns) got messed around with in Dark Souls 3 and it's mostly a worthless stat now since the effectiveness of being stun-immune now heavily depends on which weapon you're using (you're less likely to get stunned using a two-handed Zweihander versus a one-handed Axe). I don't mind hyper-armor (essentially, Poise whenever you attack, during certain parts of your attack animation), but it does make feel Poise feel a bit useless as a result.  The balance isn't great as well. Heavy Armor is essentially useless and the game really pushes you into being a lightly armored warrior with a sword-and-board playstyle (Hell, if you play as the Knight class, you have some of the best equipment in the game off of the bat). Don't get me wrong, there are plenty of viable playstyles (such as the fire-wielding Pyromancers), but they generally require a lot more investment/item-hunting/skill on behalf of the player.  Also, invasions in this game are absolute trash. More often than not, if you're the invader, you'll be summoned into a world with three people waiting to clobber your ♥♥♥. You also have 1/2 the healing/mana recovery charges you normally do (heavily punishing casters) and 30% less health than the host. It's also very hard to punish players since rolling is so incredibly powerful (and this affects duels as well). So sadly, until we get some more patches in, PvP really isn't worth bothering with unless there's a specific covenant item you want to farm or if you like the novelty of it. Thankfully, coop is a lot better, and password matchmaking means that playing with friends is the easiest it's ever been in the series.  Also, new game plus isn't great. I mean, it exists, but considering how Dark Souls 2 offered different enemies spawns, new enemies in existing locations, etc. (as well as the bonfire ascetic mechanic), Dark Souls III really does feel like a step back here.   Overall? Is it worth the purchase? Absolutely. It's deep, engrossing, and offers you a lot of value (first run can easily take a few dozen hours). PVE is definitely worth the price of admission and last you for a very long time if you enjoy experimenting with builds, even if PVP isn't all that great.  TL;DR Fantastic PVE game (best in the series for me), meh PVP game. Definitely worth the asking price.

This game, oh man, where do I even start? I am absolutely in love with this series; I can't lie, but is this game a perfect lovechild of Demon Souls, Dark Souls I & II and Bloodborne? Maybe. Lets take a look. If you are familiar with the franchise and you like it, then what the hell are you waiting for? Get this game. Now. If you are somewhat new, also get this game. You can always go back to previous games in the series after you're done with this one. Of course, you might enjoy the lore of the game more if you've played the previous ones, but you are not gonna miss out on anything gameplaywise. In terms of gameplay, this game IS perfect. Combat is smoother than ever, with the addition of Bloodborne's focus on aggressive gameplay, while it still retains the formula of DS1 and 2. There is a decent number of bosses in the game, and very few of them are bad or dissapointing; Dark Souls 3, in my opinion, is the best one in terms of bosses, even found my new favorite boss in this one. Areas are pretty big and have an interesting design. Soundtrack is absolutely amazing, as usual. NPC's are pretty cool, there are couple of pretty interesting ones, while I'm not a big fan of how they did questlines in DS3. There are a ton of weapons and armor in the game, and there are quite a decent amount of unique ones, with cool moveset and weapon arts. Now, where does Dark Souls 3 fall short? Dark Souls 3 lacks innovation. Souls veterans might feel a little fed up with the series when there is nothing really new. Sure, weapon arts is new, and for those who haven't played Demon Souls, like myself, FP (mana) is a complete new stat. It is pretty cool that you can decide if you want to have more estus or ashen flasks in your inventory. Now, I'm not saying its bad that there is nothing innovative, but I can see why people might feel this way. Maybe its for the best that Miyazaki decided to end the series with this game (other than already announced DLCs for DS3. Whether or not its true that this is the true end of the series, we'll see.     For the final verdict, I'm giving this game 9,5/10. If you are a fan of the series, you'll feel like home. If you are new to it, this is where your magical journey begins. This game made me enjoy the series even more, so much that I'm gonna play them all over again. This is the series that I'm never gonna get fed up with.      Pros:   - Return of our lord and saviour Miyazaki - Level design - Amount of content - Fluid combat - Challenging and pretty creative bosses and enemies - Soundtrack    Cons:   - PC port is not so great - Couple of dissapointing bosses - Little bit of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ enemy mechanics here and there

6/8/16 - This will be a list of Pro's and Con's and a small or big blob of information with a very short TL:DR right after it. It's a lover of the souls games so take this gamer's review with some speculation/salt.  Pro -Smooth silky gameplay, far better than it's first two father and mother. -Slightly (Or massive depending on your PC specs) improved visuals. -Better PVE in terms of connectivity and bosses. -Weapons arts. Basically each weapons have some sort of special attack making it slighty more unqiue than it's predecessors. -Soul Memory no longer exists. -NG and NG+ and onward can be played and invaded. -Summoning in PVE can be done with anyone so long as a password is added. Doing this scales both players levels. -New addition of different types of phantoms (Good one's being the Mad phantom and Ald. Faithful) -Enemies no longer have a spawn limit and will respawn like enemies from DS1. -The ending of the game is a nod to the previous souls players, much the entire game is but the end boss truly is a sight to behold. Brought a tear to my eye and worthy of a positive I should think.  There are plenty more but these are more or less (Exception of the last one) which I think are Objective good for the game.  Con -No poise (Working as intended? A joke) -Variety in PVP. A serious lack of originality. You'll see mostly Dark Swords, UGS's, Rapier's, and Caestus's. (It's obvious why but truly not a big issue for some. Depending on who you ask magic I.E, Mircale users, Pyromancers and Sorcerers have issues in terms of builds). -Ease of game. Dark Souls is usually known for it's difficult gameplay, I however have found it to be satisfactory but others I hear aren't having the ball breaking experience like the previous games (Especially those Bloodborne DLC fanatics). -Minor bugs still exist and this game had a far cry from a good launch experience. -Once you clear a boss in that area you can't be invaded in it. (Trivial I know but I've been reading reddit forums and friends tell me it's an issue). -Darkmoon Cov, Blue Sent, and Watchdog's apparently have connectivity issues. In these terms I mean they usually don't get summoned in for fights partly because these Covenant's depend on an area to invade or a particular condition for an invasion aswell as the normal invade requirement. (Blue's have to have people in the way of the blue covenant to even be summoned, Watch Dog's have to have people walk around in a area so they can be summoned however this conflicts with the whole 'You killed a boss here? looks like you won't be invaded here ever until you beat the game again and go through this area'.) -Advantages are usually in favor of the Host during invasions. This barring the fact they aren't alone. Things like Giant seeds, Dark Moons, Blue Sentinels, White phantom summons, Yellow phantom summons, and possibly more that I don't even know about or haven't mentioned. Gank squads are the norm now and if you invade you must be prepared to fight more than one person usually. Especially since invasions are primed for multiple people in one game.   Now I know there are plenty more postitives and negatives and I know that I haven't listed a lot of them here, probably because most are people's nitpicks and are mostly subjective in my eyes. Phantom ranges on some weapons, invaders who invade have to walk back to their souls, dried finger adds and extra helpful phantom as well as a chance to be invaded by two phantoms, armor upgrades no longer exist, invaders have estus, blah blah blah. I won't list these and many more for they can be argued both ways. I think the game is more than what I thought I was going to get. I absolutely play this tons and will for the ongoing future assuming the game continues it's course or gets better (Which I hope it does). In short I think this game is a solid Seven. Now before you get angry just hear me out. A five is average, anything below is below what is normally accepted in games. If your a six then you've pretty much flown above most games. While Dark Souls 3 is far from perfect I think it strives pretty damn hard for a high ranking and totally is better than most games out there.   TL:DR - Game's good, beware of issues with game mechanics and PVP could be done better. PVE is good though.

Dark Souls 3 is more Dark Souls. With the muddling of some good features with some questionable choices, it's hard to say whether or not this sequel is 'better' or 'worse,' but it's most certainly 'more'. To that end, fans of the series or of gloomy, skill-based action games will be getting more of what they love, but this game probably won't make new converts of anyone. (It is a sequel, though, so maybe that's to be expected?)  Personally, I love From Software's Souls series, and though I don't think I'll ever recapture the feeling of playing Dark Souls 1 for the first time, this game gets me close to some of those experiences. I really love the detail work in the art design, and there were multiple moments that gave me the same feelings of wonder and discovery that the best parts of Souls games can bring. There are some baffling game design choices, particularly in the area of covenants and invasions, but these don't affect my primary reasons for playing the game -- there's still plenty to discover and a lot of challenge to overcome.   Much like previous games, I'd recommend going in mostly blind for your first playthrough, with a helpful friend or forum available if you have questions. Dark Souls 3 pretty much nails the sense of discovery and ramping challenge, and it would be a shame to ruin much of that by relying on wikis, if you ask me.  After playing through the game twice, I can't really say that Dark Souls 3 is entirely innovative. There are plenty of interesting ideas and original challenges, but there are also some retreads and plenty of callbacks. There was definitely enough to keep me interested and on my toes, but I'd wished for more creativity after hearing how incredible Bloodborne (by the same company) was.   So, as I said before, Dark Souls 3 is more Dark Souls, with all that comes with it. It can at times be more of the same, but that same was really good to begin with. There are ups, there are downs, there are very pretty graphics. It could have been even better, but even an average Dark Souls game is like an average meal at your favorite restaurant -- still your favorite, though perhaps more familiar than astounding.

After 'completing' the game, I can safely say that this is tied for my favorite From Software game with the original Dark Souls. Everything I hated about Dark Souls 2 has been removed (max health decreasing when you die, boring boss fights, a world that seemed patched together at the last minute, only one ending). The addition of the focus bar is awesome and makes both melee have more options and makes magic more appealing. At the time of this writing, I have 25 hours of game play and while that might not seem like a lot for 'beating' the game, I have much more to do. I missed most of the NPC side quests, I know of at least one area I missed entirely, from what I understand NG+ contains new items and enemies that NG doesn't, and I want to try a bunch of different builds. Also I have played DS1, DS2, and Bloodborne so while I might not be the best souls player, I know what I'm doing. Someone who's never played a souls game will take much longer to complete this.  Now while I wholeheartedly recommend this game, there are still some cons as there are in any game. Some of the boss fights aren't as good as they could be. I don't want to give any specifics so as not to spoil anything, but there's at least one boss that relies on a gimmick to beat and once you know that, it's no longer interesting. The frame rate dips even on my GTX 980 TI and while it was never during anything important, it's still noticeable. It really only happens when I'm picking up items which is odd. The bonfire placement in this game is really off in my opinion. There have been multiple times when I would find a bonfire and then find another one less than 30 seconds later. I think this could have been remedied by not having every boss leave a bonfire when they've been beaten. Some of them make sense, but others are poorly placed. Finally, the PVP. The PVP itself isn't bad. It's pretty much the same as it always was in the souls games. What's bad is when you have a bad connection to the other player, you have no real idea what's going on. One minute you're trying to bait the guy to attack you, then all of a sudden you're being backstabbed. When the connection is good, PVP is a blast.  Back to the good stuff. Boss souls are much more useful now. Each soul makes two items and they're not limited to weapons but also shields and rings. Covenants now only require you to find them and you'll get an item you can swap out to be part of a different covenant. Fast travel is back and behaves the same as it did in DS2. All of the NPC's are interesting and some make a return from previous games. Each area is breathtaking and an absolute joy to explore. One area in particular, which again I won't spoil, made my jaw drop when I saw it. There's an overwhelming amount of weapons and armor to get in this game which is going to lead to really awesome builds. Finally, the lore of this game is amazing. I wanna give a shout out to VaatiVidya on YouTube. His lore videos on the first two Dark Souls as well as Bloodborne are amazing and I can't wait to see what he makes for this game.   If you're on the fence about buying this game, don't let the infamous Dark Souls difficulty dissuade you. Yes the game is hard but that's not why most people love these games. It's because of the amazing world that lets you play how you want, the very deep lore that links both previous games to this one, and the fact that is doesn't hold your hand, but lets you figure things out for yourself. I can't wait to spend many more hours with this game and I can't wait to see what the expansions have in store.

I've finished the game a few days ago, so it's time to attempt a review! No spoilers ahead.  Overall, I've grown to really like Dark Souls 3! In my book Dark Souls 1 is one of the greatest games ever made. If I had to I would rate it a 98 with only minor polish complains if any. For Dark Souls 3 then in comparison I would give something like 90. It lives up to the name and in many ways it improves upon the original game.  + The visuals are stunning. It's not so much that every texture is 4k+ or that the technology is 'next gen'. It's the big picture that really wins this argument. The environments and graphics are cleverly made so it's both performance efficient and amazing at the same time.  + The combat is butter smooth and the animations are fluid. It's very similar to Dark Souls 1 but it's faster and there is more of everything. + The enemies you fight are varied, deadly and offer a satiating challenge (during solo play). There is a little bit of recycling here and there, but not much. + The zones are massive, interesting, hold plenty of secrets, tell stories, and feel unique. One of the strongest points of the game. + You have extreme freedom in your character build. With the 70% equipment weight limit for most builds, and the infusion system (weapon modifications) you can really make countless variations. In the past there were only a few weapons that could scale from Intelligence or Faith. Now you can just infuse almost any weapon and modify it to do so. + Character creation can finally result in good looking characters! I don't think previous Dark Souls games were terrible, but this is just better. + Quite a few nods and winks for fans of the series. Returning characters, references, secrets. + Great music score.  - The greatest weakness is the cooperative PvE experience. Summoning phantoms is somehow too powerful. I've thought about this long and hard, and I believe that it comes down to the AI of your PvE opponents. They react way too slowly, predictably and frankly... poorly to being attacked by multiple opponents. There is some sort of 'aggro' system and it's hard to describe it, but just accept when I say that killing bosses with a phantom is incredibly easy. They need to tweak the AI to present faster responses and a more aggressive and intelligent combat style. Imagine if bosses could immediately turn and tactically place area attacks to hit both opponents. It's certainly possible, yet they never do it. - Online play and PvP latency can vary greatly. Sometimes it works fine, but it can absolutely break down at a moment notice. - I personally did not like the hub design of Firelink Shrine. I would have preferred a more interconnected world, but I've got to admit that this system also worked rather well. - Covenants do not play as important role as before. You are able to switch covenant on the fly, and their effects / rewards are less interesting.

===NOTE===   RECOMMENDED WITH A CAVEAT. The current stability of the game prevents enjoyable online co op/PvP for many players including myself. The core game is great, but if you intend to purchase be aware the netcode, as of this writing, is unstable and causes floating bosses, lag, and disconnects. This can be remedied by simply playing offline or not summoning. It detracts only from the multiplayer portion and not from the core game itself. I strongly recommend this title to anyone who enjoys a well handled dungeon crawl. ===  Looking at Dark Souls III as someone who mildly poked around in Demon's Souls, rang both bells in Dark Souls then got bored, and made it about halfway through Dark Souls II before finding the rather bland level design about as interesting as the story presentation from the first game I went into Dark Souls III more interested than ever. I can't explain it.  I initially was not a Dark Souls fan. As the idea of dying then running back through respawned monsters and regressing when I inevitably die again didn't sound (and in practice wasn't) appealing. I ended up enjoying the first installment immensly as a viewer more than a player. Watching story analysis videos and reading about stuff other players had dug up interested me so much more than beating my undead head against a wall for 50 hours.  Then Dark Souls III came out. With not much else to play I decided to give DSIII a shot. The improvement of core mechanical player inputs is what allowed me to enjoy Dark Souls III as a newcomer. The refinements that Bloodborne made, Dark Souls II's improvement on the basic combat functions helped; this gameplay just 'feels good'. Which is an ambiguous and seemingly unfair way of describing why this game is so good; especially for someone in my previous shoes. The easiest way to understand what I am saying is control refinement. The core gameplay controls tighter, it makes more mechanical sense, and feels less like my backstab missed because I wasn't standing at the correct single digit degree. Enemies still have insane tracking when it comes to sweeping attacks but with the added mobility your character is given from the outset (rolling consumes less overall stamina) it is compensated for. Allowing for more confident rolling through attacks once the timing is nailed down.  Story is still delivered through item descriptions and vague creepy laughing NPCs that the player discovers by accident. This is a love it or hate it kind of thing. If you prefer story to be read out in cutscenes and presented directly this is not a story for you. If you prefer to discover items in the dark corners of the world that shed shafts of light on obscure references to things that end up being related but only after you find a different item in a different corner of a different area that will make you go 'ah ha!' then this is the story style for you.  If you don't like stories in game and just like killing stuff, then it is very much a game style for you. As the story can simply be glossed over and avoided entirely.  As noted at the heading, multiplayer in its current state is a mixed bag. When it works it's great fun. The key phrase is 'when it works'. I'll start with the issues that cause frustration. The idea in Dark Souls multiplayer is interesting. Players can either help or hinder another by being summoned to co-op or by invading and killing the host. In practice this player driven interactive mechanic is what makes Dark Souls so stressful (and fun). Being invaded is one of those 'uh oh' moments that seemingly always time out to happen when you have few estus and are far enough away from a bonfire that its just enough of a risk to run into your invader; frantically looking for a summon sign for some help.   I love this style of player interaction, it gives hosts that feeling of suspense when 'Embered' which is the state of being human from the previous games with a health increase. Summoning a stranger for help against another player is great fun as the invader tries to ruin your day.  The issue is network stability. When playing on a less than optimal connection, for instance a 1Mbs speed (which is my current speed that allows for 350 Kb/s downloads, its not a great connection but still stable enough for online gaming reasonably well.) the netcode for whatever reason is unable to compensate for slower connection speeds. Players slide around the map with no visible animations, summoned co op partners get stuck behind the boss fog wall, and entire bosses will slide around the boss room not executing any animations for the co op friend allowing for cheesing of entire boss fights. This isn't accounting for random service disconnects with the game servers.  Now the good thing is this can all be avoided by simply playing offline OR by not bothering to summon to avoid the boss cheese. However the invaders are subjected to this problem as well. By no means is this a blanket issue, but it is also far more common for players with less than optimal internet speeds, so be aware of that.  If you are a new player who is interested in the series but put off by the previous 'PREPARE TO DIE' or 'GIT GUD' don't worry. Dark Souls III is in my opinion both the most difficult of souls games but also the most accessable. The initial boss will very quickly teach you how to play the game properly. Go in with the midset of 'I am going to get my ♥♥♥ kicked, oh well lets do this.' and you will have the time of your gaming life.  Praise the sun! \[T]/

I'm only giving DS3 a positive review because I believe that if and when the game breaking stuttering is fixed, it will be one of my most favored games. The stuttering is ridiculous and its caused me to die more than once. Literally every 10 or 20 seconds (sometimes more frequent than that), my framerate drops into the low single digits for nearly 3 seconds. When entering a new area, the game freezes for up to half a minute. No amount of suggested fixes has solves this and I can only wait for this to be fixed in a patch.  At this point, I regret spending a full 60$ for a game with a widely reported bug like this that is yet to be fixed. But again, if it is fixed it's definitely worth a full 60$ price tag especially if you enjoyed DS1 or you feel nostalgia towards the challenging games of the 90's and 00's. Great level design, art design, awesome OST, but most of all the mechanics and controls are very well done. movement is fluid and responsive, weapons have an appropiately hefty feel to them when you strike and the enemy designs are diverse (mechanically and visually) and interesting as well as the environments thanks to the above average (for this genre) graphics/engine. Really in my opinion the game is really well polished in general with lots of incentive to explore and see the world design and there's overall a huge sense of scope when looking out over the various vistas that come up time to time.  I recommend it highly, but only if an when the stuttering is fixed.

It is with great displeasure that as a huge Dark Souls fan, I must say, I FREAKING HATE THE SERVERS. I have heard of people getting banned for no reason, and that some people that get banned don't even get a ban message. I'm pretty sure that's what happened to me because since day one I have not been able to connect to the servers. Overall the gameplay was fast paced, but felt lacking of something. And I finally figured it out; the level design. Do not get me wrong, the graphics and textures were beautiful, but it felt almost as linear as Dark Souls 2. Still I find myself going back to the first Dark Souls because of the level design. Another problem I found with the game was that I felt like it had almost no replayability. I beat the first in the series 15+ times and I still love it. Dark Souls 3 didn't feel like it brought anything new to the table. All of my friends and I agree that it has so many reused animations from the other souls games, just with different texures and player models. The 3rd Souls game felt like Demon Souls, DS2, and Bloodborne mixed into one game. Although still using alot of the same animations as in the first Dark Souls. Overall, I was dissapointed in the game, because like I previously mentioned, it felt repeated. As if I've already done all of these tasks I was trying to accomplish. Nothing really felt new except for only a couple areas in the game. And as I've mentioned before, it is almost completely linear with almost no reason to back-track due to the fact that you started with the teleport ability that was used in DS2. All in all, the gameplay was exciting and fastpaced, but it was hard to keep myself motivated to finish it. Remeber when you got your first souls game and finally killed that one boss after dying countless times and felt that amazing rush of euphoria afterwords? Well, I didn't feel that at all with this one. R.I.P my hopes and dreams.

What the hell will I play once I finish DS3?!?  Really tired of all the sandbox games with their side quests' broken and boring dialogues i have to click through. No time for all of that nonsense. I dreamt of sandbox RPG's when i was a kid, playing games on my C64, then Amiga. I always thought i could discover some new path or something in every game, until i was older and understood how it all works. While sandbox games of today look like they are so big and open, there is no magic and imagination is stunted with it's precreated world. A sandbox game has to be perfect to the point of an almost perfect simulation of life and it's impossible. Anyway, DS3 has nothing to do with sandbox, or RPG's for that matter. It's a super-satisfying dungeaon crawler/arcade/fight simulator with great combat and gameplay mechanics and a subtle story that leaves most to the imagination. No saves whenever you want, no reload of autosaves, no going back on choices you have made throughout the game, so you better take care in what you do. They nailed that part better than 'real' RPG's that claim how much your choices influence the outcome. Trust me, in this game, you will care about your every move. Another thing they nailed better than most 'RPG's' is the continuity of the world. As you plough along, you will feel the world as one, coherent whole. What i am trying to say is that DS beats today's RPG's, even while not trying to be one. It beats today's shooters with the level of challenge it gives you and the sense of accomplishment when you manage to move on after getting stuck and dying countless tmes. No annoying difficulty slider you can tweak in mid-game, that so many games of today suffer from and no difficulty choice at all for that matter. It beats all because it has a target you have to reach and doesn't distract you with uninportant fillers on your way to that target. Speaking from the point of view of mine from my love of RPG's, again, not because the game is Role Playing, mostly because of the dark fantasy setting - If you want to wander around some 'amazing' sanbox world, talking to mentally challenged NPC's, have encounters that you can always beat by exploiting some terrain feature, or glitch that will mess with your enemy's AI mind and call that an RPG, this is not for you. Until those games have proper AI, they have nothing to offer, no matter how far you push the difficulty slider. If you want an extremely satisfying gaming experience, in a smaller world that looks and feels great to traverse, with no silly distractions and micromanagement, with revolutionary gameplay when it comes to continuity, choices and (no)saves - try it. All 3 parts are excellent, get DS1 Prepare to Die first as to me that was the best in the series in terms of content.

Dark Souls III, the final entry in the dark medieval RPG series (allegedly) is a worthy conclusion to a franchise I hold near and dear to my heart. Dark Souls has always been one of those game that just sucks me into its world like few other do. I soak in the atmosphere, my heart races in combat, I feel the grim oppression and experience the hardships as my character does. Just the other day I began playing this game a 3:30pm and next thing I knew it was 8:00, I played for four and a half hours without realizing it. Keep in mind this is my fourth playthrough of the game as well, the fact that it remains that entrancing to me really says something. Dark Souls III feels like a greatest hits compilation of all of From Software’s previous endeavors, from Demon Souls to Bloodborne. It takes little in the way of risks but I’m surprisingly okay with that. Partially because the core gameplay works so well and the lore remains engrossing but also because this is supposed to be the farewell to the trilogy. Though the derivative nature of this game means that it inevitably suffers from diminishing returns. Some of the luster has certainly worn off after so many similar experiences but it still remains an outstanding game. The fact that the Dark Souls remains pleasurable after numerous iterations is truly a testament to how solid the concept and execution of these games have been from their origins. I could talk all day about why this franchise is great and discuss the subtle nuances of all of its aspects but brevity offers a stronger message in this case: Dark Souls III ranks among my favorite games and the proverbial franchise is my favorite of all time.

This is the latest entry in the Dark Souls series (quite possibly the final for a long time). Let me quickly introduce you to what this game actually is:  A 'Souls' game (DemonSouls;DarkSouls;Bloodborne) is a unique type of action RPG which focuses a whole lot on gameplay and good mechanics. It is more or less a linear experience with a level design that connects levels together in some sort of 'inter-conected' world (very clever indeed). It has a very dark artistic theme, a lot of death and eerie stuff, complete with an amazing orchestral/epic soundtrack (with lots of cool vocals) and great sound design. 'Souls' games are thus caracterized by their visual and sonorous beauty, compelling gameplay and mechanics and intelligent level-design overall.   I'm here to tell you if Dark Souls 3 achieves what it's predecessors did.  Dark Souls 3 feels new and refreshing compared to the other souls games, it has effectively mixed multiple elements from the older games to create this feeling :  - Spells now use 'Mana' ; You can exchange Boss Souls for gear and weapons or spells (Demon's Souls) - Faster gameplay (Bloodborne) - Good old Dark Souls   The result should be nothing short of amazing right? Well it is poorly executed in some areas:  - Spells and Miracles are bad in PvP. Most of them use up too much of your Ashen Estus Flasks and deal poor damage, not to mention those that do deal damage are impossible to land a hit with. In most cases you will run out of flasks before your ennemy dies (especially if he has some means to heal himself).  Even in PvE i haven't found spells that perticularly interested me or were that fun to use... ( i still used a mage and miracle user once or twice for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles though. )  (of course you can use Wrath of the Gods, possibly a Crystal/Simple Estoc or some lightning based builds... but that's about it) - The Poise system is non existant in this iteration of the game, or at least doesn't work the way it used to. Equipping armour doesn't seem to make you less vulnerable to hit-stun weapons such as the Estoc. You can get stun-locked easily if you aren't carefull. I find this change to be odd, but it didn't really affect me since i prefer using Hyper-Armor to tank through ennemy hits (a few frames in your attack animation with large weapons in wich you can't be hit-stunned). Otherwise dodging or outranging your opponents still work well. I still have to say that i feel the commitment to attack animations isn't as punishing as in say Dark Souls 2 since you recover really fast and can immediately turn your character around in the next attack effectively making you impossible to backstab (exept in extreme circumstances ). - Boss Souls weapons are fun to use in PvE, so fun to use in fact that i started neglecting all other weapons. Crafting my own weapons and upgrading them with my ores was most of the time worse than my newest boss weapon. Especially enchantments like Blessed which are completely useless. I even used Boss weapons in PvP ,DragonSlayer's Swordspear and Two Princes' Greatsword being my favourites.  - Some Bosses are uninspired or just a bit too easy for my taste. Some of the Lords of Cinder are surprisingly bad. Some bosses such as Lothric, Soul of Cinder, or Nameless King are weirdly some of the best bosses in the series IMO. It is very inconsistent to say the least.   Despite it's flaws Dark Souls 3 remains one of the best RPG released in 2016. It is beautiful and has awsome and epic boss battles. It's ending boss is incredible and worthy of an end game boss (Soul of Cinder who represents all player fighting styles mixed together which makes for a thrilling boss fight), a real challenge with epic music and multiple forms increasing in difficulty as it tries to stop you from achieving your goal. Despite the lack of real story, it still has the interesting characters who speak with a weird accent and the bits and pieces of information that you can link together and imagine what you want for a story.   Dark Souls 3 won't hold you hand and will let you play the game the way you want to, feel free to disregard my opion on PvP combat and create your own meta if you wish, there are tons of possibilities. After all Dark souls is known for having a lot of potential for trolling and other fun stuff because of it's sheer amount of customization.   All I can say is ... I want more . 8/10

The Dark Souls franchise will forever be my favourite games series. Months before DSIII was released I began having dreams of playing it, so it become pretty obvious that I'm a tad obsessed with it. So it was a relief that when it released it turned out to be a truly fantastic game.   While it is true the game is more linear than the previous titles, I consider it far more consistent in the quality of the areas. And while the areas don't interconnect to eachother in any way similar to the first game, they interconnect upon themselves far more elegantly. The weapon arts system adds a welcome layer of depth to the already engrossing combat, making it possible to pull of some fancy manoeuvre with each encounter.  A strong and final entry to a series I am deeply in love with.

Dark Souls 3 is, by game standards, an excellent game. However, by the standards of the Soulsborne series, it falls a bit short. One of the largest issues (in both PvE and PVP) is that the amount of stamina consumed per roll is insanely small, thus allowing for spamming and removes the need to carefully time rolls in order to dodge attacks. In addition, Estus healing is much faster and powerful than the other games, making mistakes less punishing. I've seen many others complain about how the PVP system is cracked due to hosts having a significant advantage over invaders, but honestly, it's not that bad. Sure, the invader has less Estus and less health, and the host has a variety of ways to kill the invader (turning the mobs against the invader or summoning multiple phantoms), but invading was MEANT to put you at a disadvantage. In fact, in the first Dark Souls game, invaders COULD NOT HEAL during invasions. And it isn't all that often that you'll meet someone with multiple phantoms or a Seed of the Giant used; most people enjoy a good fight and will avoid scummy tactics.  Furthermore, the soundtracks and ambient noises for this game is absolutely stellar, making boss fights and even just traversing through an area feel tense, mystical, foreboding. The game is beautiful in both sound, and visuals, though. Each place is well designed, with little details etched everywhere.  All in all, the game is a masterpiece and I would 100% recommend it. With nearly 300 hours sunk into playing this game and learning it in and out I'm confident I can recommend it and say it's a must buy.   First of all the thing keeping a lot of people away from the souls series is intimidation. While the gameplay is different and challenging I would not let this keep you from giving it a try. The game is entirely fair but does require skill to succeed but in turn it rewards you heavily.  To summarize dark souls 3 I would say that it is a challenging game set in a mysterious medievil universe filled with monsters, magic, epic characters, and amazing levels. Combat requires quick thinking and learning from your mistakes. You can block, roll, dodge, attack, counterattack with the many different weapons available in the game. You can pick different classes at the beginning but you can also level any stat so as the game goes on you can turn your character into anything. Mixing and matching weapons, spells, shield, and even items for your character adds an insane amount of replayability especially due to the multiplayer. The game is like a mix of zelda, metroid, elder scrolls etc. The level design feels like one long journey and is the best and most masterfully crafted of any game. Shorcuts are cleverly placed into the world and make the game feel even more connected, and some of the scenery is downright breath taking (in a destroyed and medievil looking way). This is a game that never holds your hand, and explains the story and mechanics through the gameplay itself.  PVP works by in game items that allow you to team up and join other people's world via a white stone (white phantom). Or choose to face the odds and invade another person's world with a red stone (red phantom). This is all done in the hosts campaign and enemies will still very much attack you. This makes for some insanely chaotic and fun battles seeing as how red phantoms can turn on team mates as well. While this opens up the possibility of being double or even triple teamed it's still fun and you can turn the odds in your favor with the right amount of skill.  This is a must buy. If you are hesitant don't wait. Get some hours in before the last dlc rolls out and experience this series. Learn about it and become addicted like I and many other fans have.
